title: How to be a resilient R coder without hands.
description:
Hands-free programming may seem like magic, but it is real and it has a name: Talon. It is the solution when pathologies such as tendinitis and arthritis prevent you from working on the computer.
Nancy Rebout will talk about her experience programming in R with a tendinitis pathology, and how she overcame all the issues, and she became a resilient R-coder.

title: Boook club â€œHands-On Machine Learning with Râ€ - Chp12 - Gradient Boosting
description:
Join us for our new online boookclub session discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell! On Monday December 5, we will talk about Chapter 12 - Gradient Boosting.

We learned about decision trees, bagging, and random forests in the previous sessions. But surprise: there's another variant on tree algorithms on the market, and it's called '**Gradient boosting**'.

*"Whereas random forests build an ensemble of deep independent trees, GBMs build an ensemble of shallow trees in sequence with each tree learning and improving on the previous one. Although shallow trees by themselves are rather weak predictive models, they can be â€œboostedâ€ to produce a powerful â€œcommitteeâ€ that, when appropriately tuned, is often hard to beat with other algorithms."* (Hands-On Machine Learning)

The team spirit of this book club is really flowing and so this chapter will also be presented by one of our community members Ece. Our presenter, Ece Ozler, is from Turkey. She has a graduate degree in Economics from the Koc University in Turkey and a master's in Finance from the Netherlands. She has lived in the Netherlands for almost six years now. She works for an analytics company, FI Analytics, in the banking sector. She uses R and ML to build credit scoring models; C# to build apps that use the prediction models made in R to decide to accept a loan application.

**This boook club:**
For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (probably more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters, as for example Marianna presented chapter 6, and Elena chapter 7 and 8! We are of course available to help. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm
* It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance, but feel free to do so.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print. For the slides of our previous meetings, see [https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML](https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML).

title: Year end meet-and-greet and trivia!
description:
Join us for a fun virtual event to round out the year!
Say hi to old and new R-Ladies DC members, play some virtual trivia, and give us your feedback for what you'd like to do next year!

description:

title: R-ladies New York End of Year Social
description:
Happy Holidays! Come celebrate how far R-Ladies New York has come this year at this fun, end-of-the-year social at Whiskey Ward. This event will be in-person, and a great gathering to close out our year!

We want to thank you all for your incredible support and for being part of the R-Ladies community. We hope to see you there!

Drinks will be available for purchase. Dress in casual or holiday gear - we welcome it all!

title: {paquetes demogRÃ¡ficos}
description: En esta charla Ana Escoto nos comparte una serie de paquetes Ãºtiles para la demografÃ­a y para otras ciencias. Desde bajar directamente a R las esperanzas de vidas y tasas de fecundidad del mundo, hasta hacer una tabla de vida singular!

title: Data Visualisation with ggplot2 - Episode 2
description:
â¤ï¸ **R-Ladies Helsinki is back!** â¤ï¸

Save your spot to learn about the basics of data visualization (and more) in R with one of the most used packages: ggplot2

**Supercell** is sponsoring our comeback series, episode 2! We will have tasty snacks and soft drinks.

Make sure you RSVP before the **4th of December**. Please send us your full name, we'll prepare name tags.

If you are a beginner in R, don't be shy! We are having an open-level event.

Prerequisites are below if you want to code by yourself during the event:

* R and RStudio installed on your machine:

\- https://cran\.r\-project\.org/bin/
\- https://posit\.co/download/rstudio\-desktop/

* Packages tidyverse, more specifically ggplot2 and dplyr installed

\- If you want to install before you arrive run this code piece *install.packages('tidyverse')*

* We will help you on the way to installation if you don't feel like doing it by yourselves.

See you soon! â¤ï¸

title: Data Science Salon NYC: AI & Machine Learning in Finance & Technology
description:
R-Ladies NYC are excited to be community partners with [Data Science Salon NYC](https://www.datascience.salon/newyork/) to promote their upcoming one-day event.

Join the only industry conference that brings together specialists in finance and technology data science field! The one-day event will take place at The Theater Center, located in Broadway's Theater District and features **speakers from** **S&P Global, Capital One, Freddie Mac, Point72, Morgan Stanley, Sofi, Federal Reserve Bank of NY and many others!**

What you can **expect from DSS NYC**:

* 200+ attendees
* 20 talks and panels covering cutting-edge AI research and use cases
* Q&A sessions with expert speakers and industry leaders
* Access the recordings of all sessions until two weeks after the event
* Surprise act!

**Must Register [HERE](https://www.datascience.salon/newyork/) to attend.**

***GET FREE PASSES!!!***
R-Ladies NYC members have the opportunity to win free passes to this event. The first 8 members to e-mail nyc@rladies.org will received a pass. In the e-mail, let us know if you want an in-person or virtual pass.

\*[Data Science Salon](https://www.datascience.salon/) is a unique vertical focused conference which grew into a diverse community of data scientists, machine learning engineers, analysts and other senior data specialists. Join the DSS experience in person or virtually and improve your skills while connecting to like-minded people.

title: Boook club â€œHands-On Machine Learning with Râ€ - Chp11 Random Forests
description:
Join us for our new online boookclub session discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell! On Monday December 5, we will talk about Chapter 11 - Random Forests.

We learned about decision trees in the previous session. But why settle for one decision tree when you can have a whole forest of them? :D Random forests are a modification of bagging. They have more predictive power than single decision trees and suffer less from tree correlation than bagging.

Our presenter is **Oussama Zidi**, a biostatistician and project manager at Urgo corporation (a wound healing specialist). He primarily uses SAS and R for stats and machine learning; and python for building apps. He has a graduate degree in applied mathematics from the University of Burgundy, France.

**This boook club:**
For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (probably more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters, as for example Marianna presented chapter 6, and Elena chapter 7 and 8! We are of course available to help. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm

title: Getting to know golem - RLadies Vienna December Meetup 2022 (HYBRID)
description:
Dear all,

Our last meetup of the year will take place in a **HYBRID** format, both online over zoom and **live at TU Wien**. Please note that family friendly time slot during the lunch break. You do not need to specify in advance whether you will participare online or live, but we would be happy to see you in person @TU if you are available.

Our speaker is **Maria Ines Plaza** who will introduce us to **golem**, a package in R to develop production ready Shiny Apps. She would guide us through the content of the book Engineering Production Grade Shiny Apps [https://engineering-shiny.org/index.html](https://engineering-shiny.org/index.html) and she will share her experience developing apps with this package and methodology. This is a 100% interactive session where you could ask questions.

Since most probably many details will not be covered in the talk due to time constraints, you could join Mari at the Data Science Cafe on 9th December at WeXelerate to go into more details.

Here is the link for the ones joining online:

https://tuwien.zoom.us/j/91887799828?pwd=VEkrRllLMGNDKzMwTUoydWhsYUhyUT09

Best regards,
Your R-Ladies Vienna Organizing Team

description:

description:

18:45 - 19:30 workshop
19:30 onwards: socializing with some drinks at bQm.

We're very much looking forward to seeing you there!
CÃ©line, Seraphina and Luisa

title: Choose your own adventure: Tools for Open and Reproducible Research
description:
\*\* Please arrive before 6 for pizza and refreshments!\*\*

Hi everyone!

Do you want to increase the reproducibility of your work but don't know where to start? Are you overwhelmed by the mountain of packages and tutorials on offer? Have you picked up a few reproducible research tools already and are trying to decide what to learn next?

We are excited for our next guest speaker Cynthia Huang, who will share her experiences and attempts at answering these questions and more at our upcoming event.

Cynthia is a PhD Candidate in Econometrics and Business Statistics at Monash University. She is passionate about the interdisciplinary work of solving complex problems and the importance of open and reproducible science. Her current research focuses on the theoretical and practical challenges of applying deep learning methods to earth observation data.

Come along to this interactive discussion workshop where we will take a walk through the growing landscape of reproducibility tools, from version control and literature programming, to project environments and pipeline toolkits, and consider how to choose the next steps in your journey towards more open and reproducible data science.

This will be a hybrid event and zoom link will be provided prior to the event. We look forward to seeing you there!

title: Winter meetup
description:
Let's meet again!

It's been three years since our first meeting! R-Ladies Bergen invites all locals in Bergen to a Winter Meetup to recharge our enthusiasm for "all things R".

Jonelle and Julia are excited to present a short introduction to the new Quarto engine ([https://quarto.org/](https://quarto.org/)) using RStudio. *If you want to try it out, make sure you have these both software pieces installed on your laptop.* Let's get together, chat, and share ideas for our next meetings.

Bring your laptop and good humor, we'll take care of some snacks!

**Looking forward to being together.**

description:
**[Agenda]**

â€¢ 19:30 \~ 19:40 (10 mins) é–‹å ´
â€¢ 19:40 \~ 20:40 (60 mins) ä¸»è­°ç¨‹ : **ä½¿ç”¨ R è™•ç†åŸºå› æ•¸æ“šèˆ‡è¦–è¦ºåŒ– Genomic Data Processing and Visualization in R**
â€¢ 20:40 \~ è‡ªç”±äº¤æµæ™‚é–“

**[Talk Information]**

R/Bioconductoræä¾›äº†ä¸€å€‹å¼·å¤§ä¸¦æ¨™æº–çš„åŸºå› æ•¸æ“šåˆ†æç’°å¢ƒã€‚æ­é…Rè±å¯Œçš„ç¹ªåœ–å¥—ä»¶ï¼Œå¾ˆå®¹æ˜“èƒ½è¦–è¦ºåŒ–é«˜ç¶­åº¦çš„ç”Ÿç‰©è³‡è¨Šã€‚å¸¸è¦‹çš„è¦–è¦ºåŒ–æ–¹æ³•åŒ…å«äº† heatmapå’ŒåŸºå› é«”åæ¨™ä¸Šçš„ä½œåœ–ã€‚åœ¨æœ¬æ¬¡åˆ†äº«ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘å°‡ä»‹ç´¹Rèˆ‡åŸºå› é«”å­¸ç›¸é—œçš„è³‡æ–™è™•ç†å¥—ä»¶å’Œç¹ªåœ–åº«ï¼Œå¦‚ GenomicRangesã€ensembldbã€SummarizedExperimentå’ŒComplexHeatmapç­‰ç­‰ã€‚æˆ‘å€‘å°‡ç”¨ä¸€å€‹è…¦ç™Œçš„è³‡æ–™ä¾†ç¤ºç¯„ã€‚é¦–å…ˆï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘æœƒç”¨é€™äº›å¥—ä»¶ä¾†è¼¸å…¥ multi-omics è³‡æ–™ä¸¦é€£çµç›¸é—œçš„è³‡è¨Šå’Œæ¨™è¨˜ã€‚æ¥è‘—ï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘æœƒç”¨ä¸åŒçš„è¦–è¦ºåŒ–æ–¹æ³•ä¾†æ¢ç´¢æ•¸æ“šï¼Œåœ¨å…¶ä¸­æ‰¾å°‹ä¸€äº›æœ‰è¶£çš„ç”Ÿç‰©ç¾è±¡ï¼ˆå¦‚ï¼šXæŸ“è‰²é«”å»æ´»åŒ–ã€MGMTç”²åŸºåŒ–ï¼‰ã€‚æœ€å¾Œï¼Œæˆ‘å°‡åˆ†äº«æˆ‘éå»å¹¾å¹´ä½¿ç”¨Rè™•ç†åŸºå› è³‡æ–™çš„ç¶“é©—ï¼Œä»¥åŠå®ƒå¯èƒ½å¦‚ä½•é©ç”¨æ–¼æœªä¾†çš„æŠ€è¡“å’Œéœ€æ±‚ã€‚

R/Bioconductor provides a powerful ecosystem to conduct genomic analysis in a standardized way. Together with the strong plotting libraries in R, it's easy to visualize the high dimension of biological data. Common visualizations include heatmaps and plotting along genomic coordinates. In this talk, I will cover R's ecosystem for genomics and the related plotting libraries, including packages like GenomicRanges, ensembldb, SummarizedExperiment, and ComplexHeatmap. We will then go through a series of examples using a brain tumor multi-omics dataset. First, we will load the dataset and demonstrate how to query the related biological information using these packages. We will then walk through some interesting biological observations (e.g., X-inactivation and MGMT inactivation) by exploring our data with different visualizations. Finally, I will share my lessons with Râ€™s overall ecosystem and how it might adapt to the future technologies and new usage.

title: Data Manipulation with dplyr - Episode 1
description:
â¤ï¸ **R-Ladies Helsinki is back!** â¤ï¸

Save your spot to learn about the basics of data manipulation in R with one of the most used packages: dplyr

**Rovio Entertainment** is sponsoring our comeback series, episode 1! We will have tasty snacks and soft drinks!
Make sure you RSVP before the **25th of November**. Please send us your full name, we'll prepare name tags.

If you are a beginner in R, don't be shy! We are having an open-level event.

Prerequisites if you want to code by yourself during the event:

* R and RStudio installed on your machine:
\- https://cran\.r\-project\.org/bin/
\- https://posit\.co/download/rstudio\-desktop/

See you soon! â¤ï¸

title: Exploring dplyr package and functional diversity metrics using plant traits data
description:
Dear rekan-rekan sekalian,
Sabtu ini, 26 November 2022, kita akan kembali mengadakan R Ladies Meet Up ke-16 dengan tema "Exploring dplyr package and functional diversity metrics using plant traits data" yang akan disampaikan oleh Tresa Zen, MSc. Pada pertemuan kali ini, Tresa akan menyampaikan materi hands on terkait penggunakan dplyr untuk data cleaning dan juga overview terkait analisis functional diversity metrics menggunakan package hypervolume & BAT. Untuk yang ingin bergabung, silakan mendaftarkan diri di link berikut: https://tinyurl.com/rladiesbogor16
Seperti biasa acara akan diadakan online jam 14.00-16.00 WIB. Untuk yang ingin ikut latihan/hands on, pastikan sudah menginstall package dplyr ya, nanti kita akan share materi dan skripnya.
Seperti biasa, semua acara R Ladies adalah free for all, jadi jangan ragu untuk hadir dan ikutan :)
Sampai bertemu!
Salam,
Ulfah

title: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"
description:
Â¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a comenzar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versiÃ³n traducida al espaÃ±ol de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes mÃ¡s!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ Â¡EstÃ¡ muy bueno!

â€¢ Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 dÃ­as para avanzar con la lectura y comprensiÃ³n del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro serÃ¡ guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

â€¢ En el primer encuentro discutiremos el capitulo nÃºmero 3 â€œvisualizaciÃ³n de datosâ€ (Â¡QuÃ© bueno, empezamos con grÃ¡ficos con ggplot2 ïŠ) https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/visualizaci%C3%B3n-de-datos.html Es necesario llegar a la reuniÃ³n con el capÃ­tulo previamente leÃ­do y trabajado. Quienes no leyeron la introducciÃ³n del libro aÃºn: adelante, es corta, y les darÃ¡ un panorama de lo que iremos estudiando. En la reuniÃ³n de organizaciÃ³n vimos un panorama de la introducciÃ³n.

â€¢ En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! Â¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÃS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO 3, DE JUEVES DE 18 A 20.

â€¢ Â¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

â€¢ Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aÃºn no se sumaron, van a recibir mÃ¡s adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que serÃ¡ nuestra principal vÃ­a de comunicaciÃ³n. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.

â€¢ Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capÃ­tulo nÃºmero 3. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo bariloche@rladies.org. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

â€¢ A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionarÃ¡. Por ejemplo, sortearÃ¡ o decidirÃ¡ quiÃ©n guiarÃ¡ el siguiente capÃ­tulo, si verÃ¡n un capÃ­tulo, medio capÃ­tulo o dos capÃ­tulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarÃ¡n lo que se viÃ³ en el capÃ­tulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir informaciÃ³n en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el cÃ³digo de conducta que encontrarÃ¡n en la pÃ¡gina.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R.

Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reuniÃ³n se enviarÃ¡ unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estÃ©n alertas al correo.

title: Book Club "Machine Learning with R" - Decision trees and Bagging
description:
Have you heard about decision trees? And do you know the concept of "bagging". Join us for another meetup for the online boookclub discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. On Monday November 21st, we discuss Chapters 9 and 10, â€˜**Decision Trees**â€™ and '**Bagging**'.

The chapter will be presented by Veerle van Son, one of the R-Ladies Den Bosch organizers! Veerle works as a data scientist at a university of applied sciences. She uses R and Rmarkdown (and soon Quarto?) for data wrangling, visualisation and reporting.

For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (maybe more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this book club, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.

If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm
* It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance, but feel free to do so.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print. For the slides of our previous meetings, see https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML.

title: [ONLINE] R-Ladies ğŸ’™ Quarto
description:
**About This Meetup Event:**
In this meetup, Mine and Julie will introduce you to Quarto -- an open-source scientific and technical publishing system that unifies and extends the R Markdown ecosystem. Through discussion and live demos, they will share how they use Quarto for authoring, teaching, and collaborating. In addition, they will also give us a glimpse into their own collaboration process for creating their Hello Quarto talk for rstudio::conf(2022). (You can find that talk at [https://youtu.be/p7Hxu4coDl8](https://youtu.be/p7Hxu4coDl8.)).

**\***This R-Ladies RTP event is a joint event with R-Ladies Santa Barbara ([https://www.meetup.com/rladies-santa-barbara/](https://www.meetup.com/rladies-santa-barbara/)).\*

**About the Workshop Organizers:**

*Mine Ã‡etinkaya-Rundel* is Professor of the Practice at Duke University and Developer Educator at RStudio. Mine's work focuses on innovation in statistics and data science pedagogy, with an emphasis on computing, reproducible research, student-centered learning, and open-source education as well as pedagogical approaches for enhancing retention of women and under-represented minorities in STEM. Mine works on integrating computation into the undergraduate statistics curriculum, using reproducible research methodologies and analysis of real and complex datasets. Mine works on the OpenIntro project, whose mission is to make educational products that are free, transparent, and lower barriers to education. As part of this project she co-authored four open-source introductory statistics textbooks. She is also the creator and maintainer of datasciencebox.org and she teaches the popular Statistics with R MOOC on Coursera. Mine is a Fellow of the ASA and Elected Member of the ISI as well as the winner of the 2021 Robert V. Hogg Award for For Excellence in Teaching Introductory Statistics.

*Julia Stewart Lowndes*, PhD is founding director of Openscapes. She is a marine ecologist and champion for making science more open, efficient, inclusive, and kind. Working at the intersection of actionable environmental science, data science, and open science, she is a Mozilla Fellow, National Science Foundation Better Scientific Software Fellow, and Senior Fellow at the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) at the University of California Santa Barbara. Julia earned her PhD from Stanford University in 2012 studying drivers and impacts of Humboldt squid in a changing climate. Recent open science/R contributions include pieces in Scientific American, Nature, 2019 useR! Conference, R for Excel Users, and the Tidy Data Illustrated Series.

**R-Ladies RTP Mission & Expected Conduct:**
All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcome to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Introduction to R Shiny
description:
Join us on **Wednesday Nov 16th at 6pm EST** for an **Introduction to R Shiny session.** Learn the basics of building interactive R data products! This instructional session will lead participants through a simple R Shiny exercise. We will build and examine the two fundamental components: the user interface and server functions. Our goal is to recognize what goes in each, how their code structures differ, and how they communicate with each other so users can directly engage with your data products.

This event is meant for people new to R Shiny, but comfortable coding ggplot graphics and writing simple functions (either custom functions or for loops).

The session will be lead by Ashton Drew, Owner and Lead Consultant at KDV Decision Analysis LLC and a certified R Shiny instructor.

Ashton runs a consultancy which specializes in data analytics and communication for decision support in the fields of resource management, conservation planning, and organizational development. Final products of her firm typically include data driven apps, interactive visualizations, and web-based decision support tools that allow decision-makers to simulate and compare plausible outcomes of alternative decisions. The act of making research results accessible and relevant often requires thinking beyond the science and data to consider the uncertainty and complexity of the decisions' context (e.g., fiscal realities, social values, legal requirements, etc.). To accomplish these tasks, Ashton offers skills gathering and analyzing data from databases, expert elicitations, personal narratives, and community workshops. She has worked with multiple federal, state, and private agencies to innovate and improve the science and delivery of environmental projects.

Prior to starting her own business, Ashton worked as a research ecologist and instructor at North Carolina State University focused on species habitat modeling and other topics in applied landscape ecology. While there, she developed and taught several courses and co-edited two textbooks: â€œPredictive Species and Habitat Modeling in Landscape Ecologyâ€ and â€œExpert Knowledge and its Application in Landscape Ecologyâ€. She continues to spend about a quarter of her time teaching, offering R courses through Transmitting Science (Spain) and Yukon Government (Canada).

title: All Aboard Transportation and Data (RSVP Link in Description)
description:
For our November Meetup, we excited to spend the evening with Mikaela Jordan and Lisa Mae Fiedler who are both seasoned professionals in the world of transportation and data analytics. Our speakers will be discussing 2 different perspectives of working in transportation and data. Mikaela is currently a Senior Data Scientist at Revel and she is reflecting on her experience in building a data science practice. Lisa is the Acting Manager of Data and Analytics at the MTA who will present on a dashboarding project using Streamlit.

\*\*\*IMPORTANT NOTE ABOUT RSVPs!\*\*\*
**This will be an online event, please also rsvp** via this **[google form](shorturl.at/cgns1)** so we can reach out to you about zoom link details closer to the event date.

**Title: Building a Data Science Practice & a Data-Driven Business from the â€œGround Upâ€: The Evolution of a Team, a Company, and Myself**

*Abstract:* Being the first IC hire at a company is a lot of things, but thereâ€™s some main things that itâ€™s been:

* itâ€™s **challenging** \- thereâ€™s a lot happening\, and thereâ€™s not always a lot of people to support the work
* itâ€™s **exciting** \- your work matters\. thereâ€™s a ton of influence & reach that your work has
* it allows for opportunities of **reflection** \- thereâ€™s typically a lot of growth in a short period of time\, so itâ€™s easy to see how far the business has come\, how far the team has come\, and how far your personal growth has come

In this talk, weâ€™ll explore the evolution of data science & decision making at Revel from several different points of view (team practices, decision making processes, and personal philosophies / work styles).

*Bio:* Mikaela has a Masterâ€™s degree in Mathematics with over 5 years of experience in data science & analytics. She has worked across multiple industries with a focus on implementing data-driven strategies and measurement. In her current role at Revel, she is the technical lead for consumer data science & analytics on the rideshare business.

**Title: Centralizing external reporting via [metrics.mta.info](http://metrics.mta.info/)**

*Abstract:* As a public agency, the MTA shares a lot of data! I will overview the past, current, and future situation of MTAâ€™s public performance metric reporting and how our recent launch of [metrics.mta.info](http://metrics.mta.info/) (beta) attempts to solve for some of the issues. I will briefly go into more detail about how the site was developed using the python package Streamlit and our plans to make the entire site open source.

*Bio:* Lisa Mae Fiedler is Acting Manager of Reporting and Analytics for the MTA. She leads MTAâ€™s open data program and is working to revamp data-driven reporting for the agency.

title: An Introduction to UI/UX in Shiny
description: This session will take you through important concepts in web development related to the design of user interface (UI) and user experience (UX) and how to apply them in Shiny. Shiny is an R framework for building web applications, and all web apps have some form of "front end" â€” whatever the user interacts with. Guided by principles from the broader UI/UX field, this session will explore how we can implement best practices when designing the front end of Shiny apps. I will try to cover both smaller, basic ways you can quickly change an app as well as more complex customisations using external packages or even modifying the underlying web technologies (HTML/CSS) directly. If you've never used Shiny, I recommend at least attempting to build a simple app before attending. There are a lot of useful tutorials for beginners available here: [https://shiny.rstudio.com/tutorial](https://t.co/uDAkTxeVBi).

title: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"
description:
Â¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a continuar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versiÃ³n traducida al espaÃ±ol de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes mÃ¡s!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ Â¡EstÃ¡ muy bueno!

â€¢ Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 dÃ­as para avanzar con la lectura y comprensiÃ³n del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro serÃ¡ guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

â€¢ En el primer encuentro de noviembre discutiremos el capitulo nÃºmero 19 â€œ[Funciones](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/funciones.html)â€, secciones [19.4-19.7](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/funciones.html#ejecuci%C3%B3n-condicional). Es necesario llegar a la reuniÃ³n con el capÃ­tulo previamente leÃ­do y trabajado.

â€¢ En base a la encuesta de horarios que hicimos, hemos definido tres grupos de trabajo con distintos horarios. Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! Â¡Por favor, anotarse solo en uno de los tres! AHORA ESTÃS EN EL MEETUP DEL GRUPO 3.

â€¢ Â¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

â€¢ Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aÃºn no se sumaron, van a recibir mÃ¡s adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que serÃ¡ nuestra principal vÃ­a de comunicaciÃ³n. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.

â€¢ Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capÃ­tulo nÃºmero 20. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo bariloche@rladies.org. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

â€¢ Cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionarÃ¡. Por ejemplo, sortearÃ¡ o decidirÃ¡ quiÃ©n guiarÃ¡ el siguiente capÃ­tulo, si verÃ¡n un capÃ­tulo, medio capÃ­tulo o dos capÃ­tulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarÃ¡n lo que se viÃ³ en el capÃ­tulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir informaciÃ³n en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el cÃ³digo de conducta que encontrarÃ¡n en la pÃ¡gina.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R.

Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reuniÃ³n se enviarÃ¡ unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estÃ©n alertas al correo.

title: POSTPONED: R-Ladies Mcr at N-Brown
description:

We're finally back with our first in person event in nearly two years and we can't wait to see you all!

Speakers include Fiona Pye and Jane Baxter from N-Brown, and Ellen and Jasmine from R-Ladies/Pets at Home

17:30 - 17:50 - Networking and Nibbles kindly provided by the team at NBrown

title: Boook club â€œHands-On Machine Learning with Râ€ #5 - Chp7 Splines - Chp 8 KNN
description:
Join us for the FIFTH meetup for the online boookclub discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. On Monday November 7, we discuss Chapter 7 Multivariate Adaptive Regression Splines and Chapter 8 K-Nearest Neighbors.

Multivariate adaptive regression splines (MARS) is an algorithm that automatically creates a piecewise linear model. The KNN algorithm identifies the k observations most similar to a new value and then uses the average response value (regression) or the most common class (classification) of those k observations as the predicted output for the new value.

These topics will be presented by Elena Dudukina, from the R-Ladies community :). Elena is a clinical specialist and a PhD candidate (awaiting defense) at the Department of Clinical Epidemiology, Aarhus University and Aarhus University Hospital. She is interested in pharmacoepidemiology, especially drug utilization and safety in pregnancy, womenâ€™s health and she is also passionate about causal inference methods and R.

**This boook club:**
For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (probably more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters, as for example Marianna presented chapter 6, and Elena chapter 7 and 8! We are of course available to help. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm
* It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance, but feel free to do so.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print. For the slides of our previous meetings, see https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML.

title: Not real VEGAN: Translate metabarcoding sequences to ecological understanding
description:
Dear rekan-rekan semua!

R Ladies Bogor ke-15 akan diadakan kembali Sabtu ini, 5 November 2022. Acara seperti biasa akan kita adakan pada jam 14.00-16.00 WIB, dan kali ini kita akan mendengarkan paparan dari Dr. Andhika Prasetyo yang akan menceritakan tentang penggunaan package Vegan di R untuk metabarcoding:
*"Not real VEGAN: Translate metabarcoding sequences to ecological understanding"*

Seperti biasa, semua acara R Ladies adalah free for all, jadi jangan ragu untuk hadir dan ikutan :)

Sampai bertemu!
Salam,
Ulfah

title: Join our team! R-Ladies NYC Board Information Session
description:
If you ever wanted to be more involved with your local R-Ladies New York chapter, it's not too late! We are looking for new members to join us as event organizers on the R-Ladies NYC Board.

This information session will be a meet and greet with current board members: weâ€™ll introduce ourselves, explain responsibilities and the expected time commitment of a board member. title: Cosas terrorÃ­ficas que pasan al trabajar con datos y cÃ³mo perderles el miedo
description:
```
Â¡Hola!
Este lunes 31 retomamos nuestras actividades con una charla y un serie de minitalleres acerca de cÃ³mo enfrentar situaciones del terror al trabajar con datos, o cÃ³mo abordar datos terrorÃ­ficos usando R.
Partiremos la jornada con una charla invitada, que estarÃ¡ a cargo de Silvia GutiÃ©rrez, de RLadies Ciudad de MÃ©xico. Silvia nos contarÃ¡ cÃ³mo los mÃ©todos mÃ¡s sofisticados y de moda no necesariamente son la mejor soluciÃ³n para resolver problemas de minerÃ­a de texto, y cÃ³mo aprendiÃ³ esto lidiando con los datos de la investigaciÃ³n doctoral que realiza en el grupo de Humanidades Computacionales de la Universidad de Leipzig.
A continuaciÃ³n, Alejandra Tapia, profesora del Departamento de EstadÃ­stica UC, nos mostrarÃ¡ cÃ³mo aplicar modelos mixtos a un set de datos sobre araÃ±as usando el paquete {broom.mixed}.
Luego, Sara Acevedo, investigadora doctoral del Laboratorio de BiofÃ­sica de Suelos UC, introducirÃ¡ el paquete {janitor}, un amuleto protector contra los horrores que a veces nos encontramos al trabajar con archivos Excel.
En el siguiente minitaller, Riva Quiroga intentarÃ¡ exorcizar en vivo un archivo Excel con un formato terrorÃ­fico, pero muy habitual, para poder hacer accesibles datos terribles que de otro modo no podrÃ­an ser analizados.
```

title: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"
description:
Â¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a continuar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versiÃ³n traducida al espaÃ±ol de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes mÃ¡s!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ Â¡EstÃ¡ muy bueno!

â€¢ Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 dÃ­as para avanzar con la lectura y comprensiÃ³n del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro serÃ¡ guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

â€¢ En el segundo encuentro de octubre discutiremos el capitulo nÃºmero 19 â€œ[Funciones](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/funciones.html)â€, secciones 19.4-19.5. Es necesario llegar a la reuniÃ³n con el capÃ­tulo previamente leÃ­do y trabajado.

â€¢ Â¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

â€¢ Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aÃºn no se sumaron, van a recibir mÃ¡s adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que serÃ¡ nuestra principal vÃ­a de comunicaciÃ³n. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.

â€¢ Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el capÃ­tulo nÃºmero 20. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo bariloche@rladies.org. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

â€¢ A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionarÃ¡. Por ejemplo, sortearÃ¡ o decidirÃ¡ quiÃ©n guiarÃ¡ el siguiente capÃ­tulo, si verÃ¡n un capÃ­tulo, medio capÃ­tulo o dos capÃ­tulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarÃ¡n lo que se viÃ³ en el capÃ­tulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir informaciÃ³n en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el cÃ³digo de conducta que encontrarÃ¡n en la pÃ¡gina.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R.

Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reuniÃ³n se enviarÃ¡ unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estÃ©n alertas al correo.

title: Intro to Quarto with Isabella VelÃ¡squez
description:
Join us to learn about Quarto from Posit's very own (RStudio's very own?) Isabella VelÃ¡squez!

Isabella is an R enthusiast, first learning the programming language during her MSc in Analytics. Previously, Isabella conducted data analysis and research, developed infrastructure to support use of data, and created resources and trainings to engage technical and non-technical audiences. Her work on the RStudio Marketing team draws on these experiences to create content that supports and strengthens data science teams. In her spare time, Isabella enjoys playing with her tortoiseshell cat, drawing, watching film analysis videos, and hiking in the mountains around Seattle.

description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about Automating the web using RSelenium.

â–¶ï¸ Invited trainer: Samer Hijjazi

Samer is a Data Analyst working in the field of higher education. He is currently working in both Human Resources and Institutional Research. He loves working in R to analyze data and automate day-to-day tasks. In addition to his work, Samer has his own [YouTube channel](https://www.youtube.com/c/SamerHijjazi) where he creates analytics content primarily related to R.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: HYBRID: Styling {ggplot2} graphics for accessibility
description:
!! Be mindful that only those participants that registered via Eventbrite (https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/hybrid-styling-ggplot-graphics-for-accessibility-tickets-442642013177) will be able to attend the event in person or receive the meetup Zoom link e to join the event. Feel free to RVSP in the Meetup event page but also make sure you register on Eventbrite !!

We are super excited to run our first hybrid meet-up event! You will be able to join in person in central London (8 Salisbury square) or online. This will be our first hybrid event so please be patient as we figure out what works best. We are incredibly excited to have Nicola Rennie join us to talk about how to style ggplot2 graphics for accessibility. There will be time for some snacks and socialising both before and after the event.

Meetup ProgRam
18:15 - In person arrivals and socialising!
18:45 - RLadies introduction
19:00 - Nicola Rennie: "**Styling {ggplot2} graphics for accessibility**"
19:45-20:00 - Questions!
20:00-20.30 Socialising

ABSTRACTS

Nicola Rennie: "Using Shiny apps for dashboards in the NHS â€“ wrangling and visualising data for tracking patient outcomes."

Choosing colours, selecting fonts, and styling your plots isn't just about making them look good, although it's certainly something to keep in mind. It's also about making sure any plots you create are accessible and interpretable to everyone. In this talk, I'll discuss good practices for styling different elements of your plots, demonstrate how you implement these in {ggplot2}, and show you how defining your own theme functions can make the process smoother.

title: Communicating Data Science: Lessons Learned
description:
**Abstract:** In this 40-minute talk, Dr. Sam Tyner-Monroe will present some lessons she's learned on how to communicate her work as a data scientist. As a data scientist who frequently communicates with lawyers (at work) and the general public (on Twitter), Sam has had a lot of opportunity to learn from her mistakes since she began her career as a data scientist. There will be plenty of time after the talk for discussion, questions, and so on, so please bring your own questions and lessons learned!

**Speaker Bio:** Dr. Sam Tyner-Monroe is a data scientist for[ Tritura](https://trituraig.com/), a technology company serving the legal industry. She holds a Ph.D. in Statistics from Iowa State University. Follow her on Twitter [@sctyner](https://twitter.com/sctyner) and follow her very cute dog on Instagram [@archie.dmv](https://www.instagram.com/archie.dmv/).

title: Book club â€œHands-On Machine Learning with Râ€ #4 - Regularised Regression
description:
Want to know more about **regularisation**? Join us for the FOURTH meetup for the online boookclub discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. On Monday October 24, we discuss Chapter 6, â€˜**Regularised Regression**â€™.

Weâ€™re delighted to announce that this topic will be presented by Marianna, who is from the R-Ladies community! Marianna is a Ph.D. student in economics, she will be defending her thesis this November after which she will start a post-doc at the University of Barcelona. About R, Marianna says: â€œI got acquainted with R a couple of years ago, to me first the data-wrangling and data visualization in R was very appealing. Currently, I am using it also for regression analyses, and I am doing my papers in Rmarkdown.â€ About the topic of this bookclub edition, regularised regression, Marianna says: â€œI wanted to do a topic that would allow me to learn new things and I hope I can apply it in the future.â€

When your model contains a lot of predictors, it is likely that your model assumptions, like â€œno multicollinearityâ€, will no longer hold. **Regularisation** is a way to deal with this problem by shrinking the model coefficients. During the meeting we will go into more detail on this topic and talk about different kinds of regularised regression.

For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (maybe more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters, as for example Marianna will be presenting chapter 6! If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.

If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**

* People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
* Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions, managing R objects, controlling the flow of a program, and other basic tasks.â€

**What to expect:**

* Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
* Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
* Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**:

* Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom. The password will be sent to you via e-mail before the meeting.
* We meet every second Monday, from 7 - 8.30 pm
* It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance, but feel free to do so.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).

The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print. For the slides of our previous meetings, see https://github.com/rladiesnl/book_club_handsonML.

title: Clinical Reporting with {gtsummary}
description:
About the workshop:

The {gtsummary} package provides an elegant and flexible way to create publication-ready summary tables in R. A critical part of the work of statisticians, data scientists, and analysts is summarizing data sets and regression models in R and publishing or sharing polished summary tables. The {gtsummary} package was created to streamline these everyday analysis tasks by allowing users to easily create reproducible summaries of data sets, regression models, survey data, and survival data with a simple interface and very little code. The package follows a tidy framework, making it easy to integrate with standard data workflows, and offers many table customization features through function arguments, helper functions, and custom themes.

In this workshop participants will learn to build, customize, and report tables often found in medical journals and other research-related publications.

About the speaker:

Daniel D. Sjoberg (he/him) is a Senior Biostatistician at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City and a DrPH candidate in Biostatistics at Columbia University. His research interests include adaptive methods in clinical trials, precision medicine, and predictive modeling. He also enjoys R package development, creating many packages available on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/), [R-Universe](https://ddsjoberg.r-universe.dev/ui#packages), [GitHub](https://github.com/ddsjoberg), and internally at MSKCC. Daniel is the the winner of the 2021 American Statistical Association (ASA) Innovation in Statistical Programming and Analytics award.

title: [UPDATE: NOW VIRTUAL] Falling into Tidyverse
description:

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcome to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

**We will be meeting in person.**

Tanya Shapiro (she/her) is a freelance analyst and content creator with a passion for data visualization. For the past five years she has worked in a number of data roles within the insurance industry, using both R and Python. title: How I use workflowr to create reproducible analyses
description:
**\*\*\* UPDATE \*\*\***
**Due to the heavy rains/flood risk on Thursday, this event will now be online only. It will start at 6pm with zoom link:**
[https://unimelb.zoom.us/j/88693982905?pwd=aENqUGVmcmNoNFpDaWd4UTRuYU5sUT09](https://unimelb.zoom.us/j/88693982905?pwd=aENqUGVmcmNoNFpDaWd4UTRuYU5sUT09)
Password: 256134

Hi everyone!

We are really excited to have Jovana Maksimovic as our guest speaker for our upcoming event.

Jovana completed her PhD in computational biology at Monash University in 2011 and Jovana was a postdoctoral researcher in Bioinformatics at MCRI before joining the Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre in 2019. She has worked in the field of Bioinformatics and Computational Biology for over 14 years on numerous data analysis and methods development projects.

In this event, Jovana will share how she uses workflowr to create reproducible analyses that are easily shareable. workflowr is an R package that supports easily creating a â€œworkflowâ€. The workflowr â€œworkflowâ€ is a simple sequence of steps that are repeated and integrated into an analysis to help make the project more reproducible and shareable. By using workflowr as part of her research, Jovana has been able to create projects whose results, figures, and development history are easily accessible on a static website, along with version controlled source code and other reproducibility safeguards.

We look forward to seeing you online.

title: Collages and Patterns: Making art in R (R-Ladies Philly October Workshop)
description:
**Collages and Patterns: Making art in R**

Have you just started creating generative art in R, or are you interested in starting? Have you tried to start the process but couldnâ€™t wrap your head around how to do it? If so, â€œCollages and Patterns: Making art in Râ€, might be of interest!
This talk will briefly introduce the concept of creating generative art in R (Rtistry) but then focus on a concept that seems to allude most: how to create the data required for generative art.
While knowledge of generative art is not required to attend, this talk does assume that attendees are comfortably familiar with the tidyverse, especially ggplot2. Attendees will learn some basic concepts involved in creating collages and patterns in ggplot2 by focusing on the logic required to generate randomized and non-randomized data sets for their rtistry! All scripts, slides, and talk materials will be available for use and review at the start of the talk.

**About our Speaker**
Meghan Harris is a self-taught R user that is currently a Data Scientist at the PCCTC at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Meghanâ€™s work allows her to work with data and create various solutions using the R programming language daily. Meghan is an advocate for using open-source software when appropriate to encourage the development of programming skills, increased analysis/evaluation autonomy for agencies, and data literacy. In Meghanâ€™s spare time, Meghan creates generative art in the R programming language.

This is an online event (zoom details will be posted here before the event). The event will be recorded and shared on our YouTube page.

title: tRansfoRmeRs
description:
R and R-Ladies meetups are back! This time we are focusing on a new topic at a new venue, but having good ol' pizza and beers after the talks :) Come and meet the core and new members of the local R community!
We will start with an introductory talk on transformers by Balint, then Misi will download images of famous NFTs, and Gergo will call OpenAI's CLIP model to generate captions for those:

**BÃ¡lint KovÃ¡cs: Transformers are taking over.**
*Data scientist @ Starschema*
Transformers are a family of neural networks that achived breakthroughs first in natural language processing, but now are adapted to many other areas. The concepts behind these models will be introduced during the talk, including the attention mechanism and how it can be adapted to different use-cases.

**MihÃ¡ly OrsÃ³s: The $3 billion ape.**
*Founder @ Bull Ranks*

**Gergely DarÃ³czi: Calling Python from R to generate image captions.**
*Sr. dir. of data ops @ System1*
Using R for image processing might raise a few eyebrows, but since calling Python (or Java, Rust, or C++) has became even easier and less surprising than running C and Fortran code at the end of the day .. we can do everything from R -- sticking to our loved user interface and programming language :) This talk will introduce a company hackathlon project, where we have created tools using R (Shiny) and Python (OpenAI's CLIP model) to auto-generate and manage captions for images.

Agenda:
18:00 Doors open
18:15 Talk by Balint Kovacs
18:45 Talk by Mihaly Orsos
19:00 Talk by Gergely Daroczi
19:30 Networking

This is a joint meetup with [Budapest Users of R Network](https://www.meetup.com/budapest-users-of-r-network/), and kindly hosted by and sponsored by Starschema.

title: Intro to Iteration with Merve Ileri Tayar
description:
Come learn about the magic of iteration (including for loops) in R with Merve Ileri-Tayar.

Merve Ileri-Tayar (she/her) is a Ph.D. student in the Behavior, Brain, & Cognition program in the Psychological & Brain Sciences Department at Washington University in St. Louis. Her research mainly focuses on learning and transfer of attentional control settings, the influence of global and local expectations on the adjustment of attention, and multiple levels of cognitive control. She enjoys using R in her research and has experience in teaching R in various classes.

Zoom info:
Meeting ID: 965 0820 0632
Passcode: 708198

title: Boook club "Hands-On Machine Learning with R" - THIRD meeting!
description:
Join us for the THIRD meetup for the online boookclub discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. On Monday October 10, we discuss Chapter 4 and 5, â€˜**Linear Regression**â€™ and **'Logistic Regression'**, presented by Martine from R-Ladies Den Bosch.
For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. We will alternate hosting the meetups. In +- 10 meetings (maybe more :) ) , we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.
**For who:**
\- People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
\- Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful\. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions\, managing R objects\, controlling the flow of a program\, and other basic tasks\.â€
**What to expect:**
\- Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
\- Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
\- Room to discuss questions and other thoughts
**Whereabouts**:
\- Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom
\- We meet every second Monday\, from 7 \- 8\.30 pm
\- It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance\, but feel free to do so\.
R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print.

title: Workshop: Writing Meaningful Alt-Texts for Data Visualizations in R
description:
For our October Meetup, we welcome Liz Hare, who will lead a workshop titled "Writing Meaningful Alt-Texts for Data Visualizations in R." Liz will introduce "alt-text" and offer guidance on best practices. Alt-text is important to incorporated into your work not only to adhere to accessibility laws but also to ensure your work reaches everyone.

During the workshop, Liz will give the audience an opportunity to share their own data visualizations and discuss how they could be improved with alt-text. So, **please bring a data visualization to share with the group!**

RSVP for this workshop via Google Form in addition to the Meetup RSVP: https://forms.gle/W6UEvuwf9AJXQNHS6

The presentation is available on Liz's GitHub (for the latest slides, use this link right before the event): [https://LizHareDogs.github.io/RLadiesNYAltText](https://lizharedogs.github.io/RLadiesNYAltText)

Instructor Biography:
Liz Hare is a quantitative geneticist focusing on working dog behavior, health, and welfare. As a blind R user, she works on inclusion and accessibility of software and events.

***

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: Sentiment Analysis using R
description:
Join us for a talk on Sentiment Analysis! Using different R packages. We'll find positive and negative sentiments in texts, but also more detailed emotions such as surprise or fear. We'll learn how to visualise commonly used positive and negative words. It's suitable for all levels and you don't need any previous experience with this topic.

Manika Lamba (https://twitter.com/lamba_manika) is a 4th-year Ph.D. candidate in Library and Information Science at University of Delhi, India. She completed her MPhil and Masterâ€™s degrees in Library and Information Science from the same department. She also holds degrees in MSc Plant Biotechnology and BSc(H) Biochemistry. Her research focuses on information retrieval, digital libraries, social informatics, and scholarly communication using text mining, natural language processing, and machine learning techniques. In addition to publishing scholarly articles, she has authored a book on â€œText Mining for Information Professionals: An Uncharted Territoryâ€. As the Chair of the Professional Development Sub-Committee and Elected Standing Committee Member at the IFLA Science and Technology Libraries Section, she is actively organizing webinars to equip information professionals with new computational and digital skills. Moreover, she is serving as the Editor-in-Chief of the International Journal of Library and Information Services (IJLIS), Newsletter Officer & Webmaster at ASIS&T South Asia Chapter, Secretary/Treasurer at ASIS&T SIG-OIM, and Cabinet Representative at ASIS&T SIG-DL.

title: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"
description:

El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ Â¡EstÃ¡ muy bueno!

â€¢ Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 dÃ­as para avanzar con la lectura y comprensiÃ³n del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro serÃ¡ guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

â€¢ En el primer encuentro de octubre discutiremos el capitulo nÃºmero 19 â€œ[Funciones](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/funciones.html)â€, secciones 19.1-19.3. Es necesario llegar a la reuniÃ³n con el capÃ­tulo previamente leÃ­do y trabajado.

â€¢ Â¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

â€¢ Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aÃºn no se sumaron, van a recibir mÃ¡s adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que serÃ¡ nuestra principal vÃ­a de comunicaciÃ³n. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.

â€¢ Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el prÃ³ximo capÃ­tulo . Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo bariloche@rladies.org. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

â€¢ A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionarÃ¡. Por ejemplo, sortearÃ¡ o decidirÃ¡ quiÃ©n guiarÃ¡ el siguiente capÃ­tulo, si verÃ¡n un capÃ­tulo, medio capÃ­tulo o dos capÃ­tulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarÃ¡n lo que se viÃ³ en el capÃ­tulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir informaciÃ³n en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el cÃ³digo de conducta que encontrarÃ¡n en la pÃ¡gina.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (utilizaremos google meet). Se recomienda tener conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R.

estÃ©n alertas al correo.

title: Shut Up and Code
description:
Informal meetings where people can hang out and work on coding projects. This includes (but is not limited to) coding homework, data analysis, results visualization, and learning new R packages/skills.

Meetings are **hybrid**, with both **in-person** (Life Sciences West 509) and **Zoom** options.

title: Wrangling Data in the Tidyverse
description:
About the workshop:

Cleaning your data can be a tedious and time-consuming task. This hands-on workshop will introduce you to the tidyverse syntax and explore some functions from the dplyr package to turn your data into the format you need. You will learn to select, filter, transform variables, pivot, make some basic descriptive analyses, and more in order to make your data wrangling more efficient.

**\*** This workshop assumes you are familiar with R and the RStudio IDE. If you would like an intro to R, you can take advantage of this free course by R for the Rest of Us: [https://rfortherestofus.com/courses/getting-started/](https://rfortherestofus.com/courses/getting-started/)

About the speaker:

Joscelin Rocha-Hidalgo currently works at Penn State as a Postdoctoral Fellow looking at Parent-Child brain activity synchrony and temperament development. Joscelin received her doctoral degree in Lifespan Cognitive Neuroscience at Georgetown University, where she focused on children's cognitive development and factors such as bilingualism and media. On June of 2022, Joscelin joined the team of "R for the Rest of Us" as its first intern.

LinkedIn: [https://www.linkedin.com/in/joscelinrocha/](https://www.linkedin.com/in/joscelinrocha/)
Website: [https://www.JoscelinRocha.com](https://www.JoscelinRocha.com)
Github: [https://github.com/Joscelinrocha/Learning-R-Resources/wiki](https://github.com/Joscelinrocha/Learning-R-Resources/wiki)

title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Advanced Regression Models with R Applications
description:
PLEASE GO TO [SoCal R User Group](https://www.meetup.com/SOCAL-RUG/) MEETUP TO LEARN MORE:

The sign-up is on [Eventbrite](https://www.eventbrite.com/e/socal-rug-advanced-regression-models-with-r-applications-tickets-407225381077).

Hello:
[SoCal R User Group](https://www.meetup.com/SOCAL-RUG/) is Southern California's premier data science meetup group. They holding an event that is sure to be a great educational event.
On October 1, they will have a workshop on advanced regression techniques. Dr. Olga gave this course a couple of years ago and it was a HUGE success. The sign-up is on [Eventbrite](https://www.eventbrite.com/e/socal-rug-advanced-regression-models-with-r-applications-tickets-407225381077).

In this workshop, you will learn a variety of regression models. We will give their definitions, discuss goodness-of-fit criteria, present fitted models, interpret estimated regression coefficients, and use the fitted models for prediction. The models will be limited to linear regression, Box-Cox transformation, gamma regression, ordinary logistic regression, Poisson regression, beta regression, longitudinal (repeated measures) regression, and hierarchical model.

The workshop is designed to be hands-on. Participants are required to bring laptops and be ready to write R, analyze data and interpret results. For each model, we present an example with a complete R code, and then will an exercise to work on. Workshop participants should be familiar with algebraic expressions of different probability distributions and have a fundamental knowledge of simple linear regression: normally distributed random error, continuous and categorical independent variables (requiring creating dummy variables).

The material covered by the workshop will be taken from my recently published book â€œ[Advanced Regression Models with SAS and R Applications](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07L1B143S/)â€, CRC Press, 2018.

For more details and course content, check out the [GitHub repo](https://github.com/socalrug/advanced_regression_2022-10-01).

If you have questions please reach out to [John@JPPeach.com](mailto:John@JPPeach.com).
There is a nominal fee for this event to help cover some of the costs, such as lunch. However, there is a limited number of tickets for those that the cost of the event will create a hardship. To apply for one of these tickets please reach out to [John@JPPeach.com](mailto:John@JPPeach.com) with a brief statement of your situation.

title: Bringing your plots to cloud nine with {Plotnine}
description:
We are excited to announce our new collaboration with R-Ladies Cologne, PyLadies Tunis, and PyLadies Munich by hosting a joint meetup on September 30 at 6pm CEST.

PyLadies (https://pyladies.com/) is an international mentorship group with a focus on helping more women become active participants and leaders in the Python open-source community.

We will delve into the beauty of data visualization and explore how easy it is to transfer the logic of ggplot2 to the world of Python using plotnine ğŸ¨

âœ¨ Bringing your plots to cloud nine with {Plotnine} âœ¨
Our workshop is focused on exploring how to create and customize enticing visuals using plotnine in Python -- a visualization library very similar to R's ggplot2. By the end of the workshop, users will be familiar with basic plotnine concepts and create a total of 2 visuals using data provided by Tidy Tuesday.

title: Shut Up and Code
description:
Informal meetings where people can hang out and work on coding projects. This includes (but is not limited to) coding homework, data analysis, results visualization, and learning new R packages/skills.

Meetings are **hybrid**, with both **in-person** (Life Sciences West 509) and **Zoom** options.

title: Webscraping, Geocoding & Interactive Map-Making with Center City Sips Data
description:
Are you interested in learning how to work with geographic data? How to scrape data from the web? How to plot your geographic data and make it all interactive and interesting? If so, this beginner-friendly workshop is for you.

Join us as Silvia CanelÃ³n provides a gentle introduction to web-scraping, geocoding and map-making in an end-to-end analysis. You'll learn how to scape the bar and restaurant data from the Center City Sips website and convert the addresses to latitude and longitude. You'll learn how to plot the geographic data onto a map and customize the visualization with {leaflet} ([Check out the map](http://tiny.cc/ccdsips2022)!).

All of the code and the data will be available in an RStudio cloud project to make coding along even easier. This workshop is based on Silvia's previously shared [tutorial](https://silviacanelon.com/blog/2022-ccd-sips/#building-the-map).

**Event materials:**

* **GitHub repo: [https://github.com/spcanelon/2022-ccd-sips ](https://github.com/spcanelon/2022-ccd-sips)**
* **Slides: [https://slides.silviacanelon/2022-ccd-sips](https://slides.silviacanelon/2022-ccd-sips)**

##### **About our Speaker**

Silvia CanelÃ³n, Ph.D., is a data analyst in the [Urban Health Lab](https://www.urbanhealthlab.org/) at the University of Pennsylvania. Her research interests include applications of biomedical data science in the public and population health fields. She works on projects that use electronic health record (EHR) data and geospatial analyses to explore how the neighborhood environment and access to urban nature can impact the health of individuals in Philadelphia. Learn more about Silvia and her research on her [blog](https://silviacanelon.com/).

title: REMOTE: Using Shiny apps for dashboards in the NHS
description:
!! Be mindful that only those participants that registered via Eventbrite (https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/using-shiny-apps-for-dashboards-in-the-nhs-wrangling-and-visualising-data-tickets-414891540767) will receive the meetup Zoom link and will be able to join the event. Feel free to RVSP in the Meetup event page but also make sure you register on Eventbrite !!

Join us in our remote meetup to learn about how shiny is being used for dashboards in the NHS! Also, we're not going to give up on the tradition of after-talks socialising, which will take place in the breakout Zoom rooms. So make sure you have some snacks, drinks and some cool webcam background on (behind) you!

Meetup ProgRam
18:30 - Welcome to Rladies remote lightning talks!
18:45 - Lydia Briggs: "Using Shiny apps for dashboards in the NHS â€“ wrangling and visualising data for tracking patient outcomes."
19:15-20:00 - Remote Socialising!

ABSTRACTS

Lydia Briggs: "Using Shiny apps for dashboards in the NHS â€“ wrangling and visualising data for tracking patient outcomes."

Lydia is a data scientist in the NHS, working in the Digital Research Environment (DRE) at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Over the past two years, Lydia has been involved in numerous dashboarding, statistical and analytical projects to aid clinicians with their research and provide insights into hospital operational management and patient care. Lydia has a masters degree from the University of Nottingham in Medicinal and Biological Chemistry and completed her Chemistry PhD in 2019 from the University of Manchester, but decided to change career track in to the world of data using the STEM skills acquired through 5 years of research experience. She is particularly interested in providing training and promoting the benefits of R and coding.

title: Making your workflow work for you
description:
\*What are we going to learn?

Chloe will talk about packages that she commonly uses (tidyverse, ggstatsplot, rmarkdown, DT) . She will also give some insight into her general workflow too (e.g., directory set-up, automating repetitive QC and analysis, RMarkdown, making nice figures).

\*Who is going to present?

Chloe is a final year MD-PhD student working on autism omics (which essentially boils down to data analysis). R is her analytical workhorse and tool of choice! In spite of some of her R habits being pretty hacky, Chloe likes to think that her overall workflow is pretty efficient, and is keen to share some of her tips, and hear some from you!

Find Chloe on Twitter @doyouseewhy.

\*When are we meeting?
***The presentation will start at 6:00 pm (AEST)***

The presentation will run for approximately 45 mins with time for questions and mingling.

\*Where are we meeting?

* This talk will be held via at QUT Gardens Point P638 and on Zoom [https://qut.zoom.us/j/89192904717?pwd=OTdFRFFHU201QnhhYU1sTzd4ZHJDUT09&from=addon](https://qut.zoom.us/j/89192904717?pwd=OTdFRFFHU201QnhhYU1sTzd4ZHJDUT09&from=addon) (password 633047).

We look forward to seeing you there!

title: Switching between space and time: Spatio-temporal analysis with cubble
description:
**This is a hybrid event. This Meetup page sign up is for attending online only. Please use the following link to register if you are attending in person:** [eventbrite.com/e/switching-between-space-and-time-spatio-temporal-analysis-with-cubble-tickets-411842892177](eventbrite.com/e/switching-between-space-and-time-spatio-temporal-analysis-with-cubble-tickets-411842892177) Online session will start at 6PM. Zoom link will be provided prior to the event.

Hi everyone!

We are really excited to have Sherry Zhang as our guest speaker.

Sherry Zhang is a current PhD student in the Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics at Monash University. Her research focuses on exploring multivariate and spatio-temporal data with visual and exploratory data analysis tools. This year, Sherry organises the Monash NUMBATs seminar, the bi-weekly meetup of the Monash Business Analytics Team.

This will be a hands-on session to work with some Australian weather station data. Australia weather data have a spatial component given by the station coordinates and a temporal component that provides daily measures of precipitation, and maximum/ minimum temperature. We will use the package \`sf\` to work on the spatial side to generate some maps (bonus point if) and the package \`tsibble\` to conduct some exploratory data analysis on the temporal side. One way to communicate space and time information together is through a glyph map where temporal coordinates are transformed into space. We will create the glyph map with the ggplot geom: \`geom_glyph()\`. Lastly, we will experiment with a new data structure, cubble, to arrange spatio-temporal data.

We are looking forward to seeing you all in person and online! Don't forget to sign up via the eventbrite link if you will attend in person.

R-Ladies Melbourne
