title: Boook club "Hands-On Machine Learning with R" - Second meeting!
description:
Join us for the second meetup for the online boookclub discussing **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. On Monday September 26, we discuss Chapter 3 and 4, â€˜**Feature & Target Engineering**â€™ and â€˜**Linear Regression**â€™, presented by Ale from R-Ladies Utrecht.

For this boook club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R Ladies - are joining forces. In +- 10 meetings, we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this boookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**
\- People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
\- Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful\. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions\, managing R objects\, controlling the flow of a program\, and other basic tasks\.â€
**What to expect:**
\- Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
\- Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
\- Room to discuss questions and other thoughts
**Whereabouts**:
\- Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom
\- We meet every second Monday\, from 7 \- 8\.30 pm
\- It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance\, but feel free to do so\.
R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).
The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print.

title: Book club "Hands-On Machine Learning with R" - Second meeting!
description:
Now that summer is coming to an end, we thought it would be fun to work through another book together. This time, we have chosen **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell.
Nowadays you hear about machine learning all the time. This book is a nice way to get familiar with the basics of machine learning in R without going in too much detail.

For this book club we - the Den Bosch and Utrecht chapters of R ladies - are joining forces. In +- 10 meetings, we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this bookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.

On Monday September 26, we do Chapter 3 and 4, â€˜**Feature & Target Engineering**â€™ and â€˜**Linear Regression**â€™. If you cannot make it this time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who:**
\- People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
\- Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful\. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions\, managing R objects\, controlling the flow of a program\, and other basic tasks\.â€

**What to expect:**

\- It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance\, but feel free to do so\.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/).

The book can be found at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/). It is also available in print.

title: Vancouver Datajam's Datafest 2022
description:
We are pleased to announce that Vancouver RLadies has teamed up with Vancouver DataJam to bring you [Datafest 2022](https://twitter.com/VanDatajam/status/1568286936661651457?s=20&t=1qsA_DIizCiS9PaZ7f0L9A)!

Vancouver DataJam's Datafest 2022 is a week-long workshop series from September 26th - October 1st, where you can develop your coding skills and meet other community members. Participating groups include RLadies, PyLadies, Women in Machine Learning/Data Science, SFU Scientific Programming, and Women Techmakers.

This event series celebrates tech talents here in BC and encourages more people, especially those from underrepresented backgrounds, to participate in the community. Our workshops cover various topics, including R, Python, MLOps, and inclusive instructor training. Each workshop will either be held in-person or virtually for 2-3 hours led by some of Vancouverâ€™s most talented data practitioners and multiple teaching assistants.

We aim to foster a beginner-friendly environment and to increase the visibility of WoC and gender minorities in the fields of data science and technology. If you have any questions or concerns about the event please contact Sheia at [vancouverdatajam@gmail.com](mailto:vancouverdatajam@gmail.com)

The registration deadline is 2 days before the workshop. Please note we have limited capacity and you may be added to a waitlist.

For [registration ](lnkd.in/eziJycqi)and the most up-to-date details, follow [Vancouver DataJam](https://twitter.com/VanDatajam/status/1568286936661651457?s=20&t=1qsA_DIizCiS9PaZ7f0L9A) on Twitter.

**Registration form:** https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeaaGUrtPKYdtkC3wsxc4eD5k1y-olhyocjjam1diOJtzIL5w/viewform

**Twitter:** https://twitter.com/VanDatajam/status/1568286936661651457?s=20&t=1qsA_DIizCiS9PaZ7f0L9A

12:00 Break/ SesiÃ³n de convivencia (10 min)
12:10 Mega plÃ¡ticasÂ¿CÃ³mo aplican R ciertas especialistas MatemÃ¡ticas, ciencias sociales, bioinformÃ¡tica, ecologÃ­a
* 12:40 SesiÃ³n de networking / Clausura

**TALLER Rladies Cuernavaca**
GrÃ¡ficas con ggplot2

**DESCRIPCIÃ“N**
En este taller (que se llevarÃ¡ a cabo en el marco del 3er encuentro anual de RLadies MÃ©xico), mostraremosmos la estructura general para generar grÃ¡ficos con ggplot2, en tÃ©rminos de la estÃ©tica y la geometrÃ­a, partiendo de un conjunto de datos determinado.

**SOBRE LA PONENTE**
Ernestina Godoy es la Jefa del Departamento de BioinformÃ¡tica en Enfermedades Infecciosas del Instituto Nacional de Salud PÃºblica, que da apoyo transversal en Ã¡mbitos de secuenciaciÃ³n masiva y anÃ¡lisis bioinformÃ¡tico a los investigadores de ese Instituto. Sus lÃ­neas de investigaciÃ³n son anÃ¡lisis del repertorio de anticuerpos en condiciones de salud, enfermedad y vacunaciÃ³n, la genÃ³mica comparativa de aislados clÃ­nicos de importancia en la salud pÃºblica, asÃ­ como MetagenÃ³mica aplicada a enfermedades infecciosas. Durante su doctorado formÃ³ parte del desarrollo de ImmunediveRsity, un software especializado para el anÃ¡lisis de secuencias de anticuerpos. Sus intereses son la BioinformÃ¡tica, el Desarrollo de Software, la VisualizaciÃ³n de datos y la EnseÃ±anza.

**REQUERIMIENTOS DE SOFTWARE**

* R >=4.0 y RStudio en su versiÃ³n mÃ¡s actual
* Paquetes de R: ggplot2, reshape2
Puedes usar la instrucciÃ³n de instalaciÃ³n:

title: How to spatial modeling with R
description:
Join us for the first autumn event of RLadies DC meetups 2022-2023.

Pass code 000111

This event is meant for people new to spatial analysis and modeling with RStudio but comfortable in making simple data visualization with ggplot2.

* Federica will show you how to make a map with RStudio.
* How to use data modeling for making spatial model analysis.
* Youâ€™ll be able to make a map by the end of the session.
* It is helpful to have the following R packages installed beforehand: {tidyverse}, {ggthemes}, {maptools}, {ggmap}, {spdep}, {sf}, {spocc}, {dismo}, {SpatialEpi}, and {oregonfrogs} from remotes::install_github("fgazzelloni/oregonfrogs").

Speaker Bio: Federica Gazzelloni is an R enthusiast and has been practicing R spatial participating in the #30DayMapChallenge competition on Twitter last year. She is a mentor within the R4DS community learning on slack and recently participated as one of the diversity scholars at the RStudio::conf2022. She is also an author in the health sector and looking to be more involved with investigations. Prior to that, she taught Mathematics at a high school in Rome and provided professional guidance on how to use excel for work at the European University of Tourism. She loves making data visualizations and applying statistical techniques for model forecasting.

title: R-Ladies NYC Lightning Talks - RSVP and Call for Speakers
description:
We are excited to host an online version of one our most popular events - R-Ladies NYC Lightning Talks!

Fill out this brief form by Thursday, September 1st to submit your application to be a speaker!
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1vXC-iKiqCycnwD4sjqYMm9BgIOITHEvsPPdZBrVlEjg/edit

Lighting talks are five minute talks. You can talk about anything R, Tech, and/or Data Science related. Looking for ideas? How about talking about a cool package you found, how you use R in your company, a favorite learning resource, your journey into Data Science, or a side project you've been working on?

We would especially love to hear from people who've never presented at a meetup or conference before and/or those who still don't feel confident speaking publicly. A lightning talk can be a great way to start out speaking, as it's quick, low-prep, and fun!

Interested in proposing a talk but want to brainstorm ideas, get feedback, or some encouragement? We're here to help! You can join the #lightningtalks channel in our slack channel or email nyc@rladies.org. We would be happy to set up a time to talk with you!

Tonight's lineup of speakers is:

1. **Clara Wang: Using Shiny to Avoid Boring Tasks at Work**
2. **Crystal Lewis: A Comparison of Packages to Generate Codebooks in R**
3. **Blaire Hamelehle: Mapmaking Data Stories**
4. **Susmita Paul, Northwell Health: Logistic Regression in the Tidyverse**
5. **Natalia Andriychuk: Creating an R Center for Excellence in a large pharma company**
1. **Twitter: @datascienceandi**
6. **Daniela Cortez: Air Analytics**
7. **Dorota Rizik: Base R vs. Tidyverse: Regular Expression Edition**

To celebrate the diversity in the R Community, we're prioritizing presenters who identify as a minority gender (including but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender).

Important Dates
\- Submissions due: Thursday 9/1
\- Notification of acceptance: Sunday 9/4
\- Speakers to Confirm Participation: Wednesday 9/7
\- Submit slides to R\-Ladies: Friday 9/16
\- Lightning Talk Event: Tuesday 9/20
\-\-\-
This event will be hosted over Zoom -- the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event, and the passcode will be shared via email.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at nyc@rladies.org.

title: Introduction to R (virtual)
description:
Join the Seattle R-Ladies in this 1-hour, virtual workshop where we introduce you to R and RStudio at the beginner level. In it, we cover:

* R and RStudio including projects, scripts, and packages
* The help function
* Reading in data as a data frame and RData
* Data types

**Pre-requisites**
You **do not** need any prior experience in R or coding!

**Materials**
[https://bigslu.github.io/workshops/introR.workshop/introR.html](https://bigslu.github.io/workshops/introR.workshop/introR.html)

**In-person social**
Those in the Seattle area are invited to join us at our end of summer social after the workshop! Please RSVP to this event separately on Meetup at [https://www.meetup.com/rladies-seattle/events/288438564/](https://www.meetup.com/rladies-seattle/events/288438564/)

description:

title: September BookClub - ISLR Tidymodels Lab
description:
R-Ladies Philly is launching a series of bookclub meetups to promote community-supported learning experiences. The nominated book for this year is [An Introduction to Statistical Learning (ISLR)](https://www.statlearning.com/). To differentiate our group from the on-going bookclub at [The R4DS Online Learning Community](https://r4ds.github.io/bookclub-islr/), we will focus on application for [tidymodels](https://www.tidymodels.org/) using the [ISLR-tidymodels labs](https://emilhvitfeldt.github.io/ISLR-tidymodels-labs/index.html) that were kindly authored by Emil Hvitfeldt.
Everyone is welcomed to participate in the bookclub. To enhance the learning experience, there will be volunteers to lead the bookclub at each monthly meetup. The volunteers will give an 20 \~ 30 minutes summary presentation on the chapter. The presentation format will either be overview of the chapter, applying the chapter content to a mini-data project, or another preferred format. It will be followed with community-driven Q&A.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:10 Join Online
6:10 - 6:20 Welcome and Annoucement
6:20 - 6:50 Chapter 7 Moving Beyond Linearity (TBD)
6:50 - 7:20 Chapter 8 Tree-Based Methods (Lisa Lendway)
7:25 - 7:55 Discussion

**If you are interested in volunteering to lead bookclub, please sign up [here](https://tinyurl.com/rladies-bookclub)**

title: How to Send Email With R
description:
Abstract: See how to generate and send email right from R with two different packages, including setting up Gmail authentication and best practices for securely storing authentication credentials.

About the speaker:
Sharon Machlis is a long-time technology journalist who is currently director of editorial data & analytics at Foundry, publisher of Computerworld, PCWorld and other tech media sites. She writes about R for InfoWorld, hosts InfoWorldâ€™s Do More With R video series, and is the author of Practical R for Mass Communication & Journalism (CRC Press).
Website: https://www.infoworld.com/author/Sharon-Machlis/; https://www.machlis.com/index.php (Please have a look at Sharon's photography - it's stunning)!

title: Boook club "Hands-On Machine Learning with R" - First meeting!
description:
**Details**
Now that summer is coming to an end, we thought it would be fun to work through another book together. This time, we have chosen **â€˜Hands-On Machine Learning with R**â€™ by Bradley Boehme and Brandon Greenwell.
Nowadays you hear about machine learning all the time. This book is a nice way to get familiar with the basics of machine learning in R without going in too much detail.
For this book club we - R-Ladies Utrecht and R-Ladies Den Bosch - are joining forces. In +- 10 meetings, we will work through all the chapters in the book together. We are doing this bookclub, because we like to learn together. It is not the case presenters are the experts on the matter. To make this a group effort, the idea is that all participants take turns in presenting chapters. If youâ€™re not comfortable presenting, just listening is also okay.
On Monday September 12, we start with the first two chapters, â€˜Introduction to Machine Learningâ€™ and â€˜Modeling Processâ€™, presented by Gerbrich from R-Ladies Utrecht. If you cannot make it the first time, feel free to join in on one of the subsequent meetings.

**For who**
\- People who want to take their first steps into machine learning
\- Some prior knowledge on R programming will be helpful\. As the authors of the book themselves mention: â€œThis book is not meant to be an introduction to R or to programming in general; as we assume the reader has familiarity with the R language to include defining functions\, managing R objects\, controlling the flow of a program\, and other basic tasks\.â€

**What to expect**
\- Presentations summarising the key points on each topic of the book
\- Putting the theory to practice by going through exercises together
\- Room to discuss questions and other thoughts

**Whereabouts**
\- Meet every 2 weeks via Zoom \[url will follow later\]\.
\- First meeting is at the 12th of September 2022\, 7 \- 8\.30 pm
\- It is not necessary to read the chapters in advance\, but feel free to do so\.
The book can be found online at [https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/](https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/) ,. It is also in print.

**Code of Conduct**
R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. See the [code of conduct](https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/) .

title: Keeping it Tidy: Using the Tidyverse to Organize, Transform, and Visualize Data
description:
We are so excited to announce the start of our activities within R-Ladies Paris.

We are so pleased to be hosting Meghan Hall who will animate a practical session about the use of Tidyverse in R. The tidyverse (https://www.tidyverse.org/) is an opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science. All packages share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structures of tidy data.

â¡ï¸ Place: Online on Zoom
â¡ï¸ Date/Time: September 8, 2022 from 7pm to 8:30pm CEST

â¡ï¸ About the workshop:
R makes it possible to work with and analyze data in an efficient and reproducible way. This workshop is targeted toward beginners and will serve as an introduction to the tidyverse, a collection of packages designed to aid in the cleaning and wrangling of data. In order to give you the tools to embark upon your own analysis on your own data, we will work through a sample data set and discuss methods for modifying, aggregating, reshaping, and visualizing data.

â¡ï¸ About our invited trainer:
Meghan Hall (https://meghan.rbind.io/) has spent over seven years as a data professional in higher education. She also has experience in sports analytics, as an ongoing contributor to the public community and previously as a data scientist at Zelus Analytics. She is dedicated to R education, particularly for beginners, and frequently delivers talks, workshops, and classes.

â¡ï¸ Requirements:
âœ”ï¸ R & RStudio installed
âœ”ï¸ Tidyverse installed by running install.packages("tidyverse") in R

In order to attend the meetup, please make sure to register on our Meetup group.

We will send you the Zoom link as well as the passcode via email a few hours before the meetup. Please check out your email later.

We are looking forward to welcoming you!

We invite you to follow us on our social networking sites to keep up to date on the latest news we will be sharing â¬‡ï¸

title: Venables Award Winners 2022 seminar watch party
description:
This online event is hosted by the Statistical Society of Australia, SSA. The registration is though Eventbrite, please click [here](https://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/ssa-venables-award-winners-2022-seminar-tickets-407730612237) for further information and to register for the link. RLadies Canberra members are also invited to attend a "watch party" in-person at the Australian National University, Hanna Neumann Building 145, room 1.33. Light refreshments will be available.

There will be three short presentations from the Venables Award winners as follows:
"Tidy ABS data with readabs" by Matt Cowgill
"Connecting to the Atlas of Living Australia with galah" by Martin Westgate
"The Vizumap R Package and VizumApp Shiny App" by Lydia Lucchesi, Sam Nelson and Petra Kuhnert.

title: The workflow of tidy data, constructing plots and making data-driven decisions
description:
Hello Ladies! We are excited to have Professor Di Cook from Monash University for our next in-person event who will be sharing the workflow of tidy data, constructing data plots, and making data-driven decisions with us.

Di Cook is a Professor in Econometrics and Business Statistics at Monash University. She primarily works on data visualisation, and have been using R for almost 30 years! Her research is in the area of data visualisation, especially the visualisation of high-dimensional data using [tours](https://github.com/ggobi/tourr) with low-dimensional projections, and projection pursuit. A current focus is on bridging the gap between [exploratory graphics and statistical inference](http://dicook.github.io/nullabor/). Technology plays an important role in data visualisation for evaluating effectiveness and for public consumption. Di utilises technology such as virtual environments, Amazonâ€™s Mechanical Turk, and eye-tracking in her work, and makes an effort to share her work with open source software. Di is a Fellow of the [American Statistical Association](https://www.amstat.org/), elected member of the [International Statistical Institute](https://isi-web.org/), past-editor of the [Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics](http://amstat.tandfonline.com/toc/ucgs20/current), elected Member of the [R Foundation](https://www.r-project.org/foundation/), and current editor of the [R Journal](https://journal.r-project.org/).

Feel free to bring your laptop and we can all work together through out the event! After the event, we will have some networking time.

The event is limited to 30 attendees so please sign up beforehand. We will provide a zoom link prior to the event. Looking forward to seeing you all!

title: Acessando a API do Google Earth Engine com o 'rgee'
description:
**ApresentaÃ§Ã£o**

O **'rgee'** Ã© um pacote para chamar a API do Google Earth Engine dentro do R. Possui vÃ¡rias funÃ§Ãµes para importaÃ§Ã£o (exportaÃ§Ã£o) de objetos espaciais do Earth Engine, extraÃ§Ã£o de sÃ©ries temporais, exibiÃ§Ã£o interativa de mapas, interface de gerenciamento de ativos e exibiÃ§Ã£o de metadados.

O **Google Earth Engine** Ã© uma plataforma que permite aos usuÃ¡rios acessar um arquivo em escala de petabytes de dados de sensoriamento remoto e executar anÃ¡lises geoespaciais na infraestrutura do Google. Atualmente, o Google oferece suporte apenas para Python e JavaScript. O pacote ' rgee' preenche a lacuna fornecendo suporte para o R.

**Palestrante**

**Dra. TainÃ¡ Rocha** \- Pesquisadora e cientista de dados que trabalha com padrÃµes de biodiversidade\, com foco nos impactos das mudanÃ§as globais\. title: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

At this event, we'll revisit one of the Tidy Tuesday datasets from June 2022 made available through Data for Progress. Specifically, this dataset is on Pride donations from large organizations to various LGBTQ+ communities. You can read more about it here: [https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2022/2022-06-07](https://www.google.com/url?q=https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2022/2022-06-07&sa=D&source=calendar&usd=2&usg=AOvVaw22fHUd5Izk_fwrjdyksOme).

Agenda (all times in ET):
6:30 - 6:45 pm Meet & Greet
6:45 - 7:45 pm #tidytuesday
7:45 - 8:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out [this blog post](https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt) and [the main repository page](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Cross-Post from SoCal RUG: I fit a model... now what?
description:
\# Abstract
This talk introduces \`marginaleffects\`, a unified interface to interpret the results of over 60 classes of models in \`R\`. \`marginaleffects\` allows users to compute and plot the key quantities of interest in most statistical analyses: predictions, contrasts, marginal effects (slopes), and marginal means. In addition, users can easily conduct hypothesis tests for arbitrary functions of a model's parameters.

\`marginaleffects\` is fast, low-dependency, actively developed, and well documented. The package website hosts an extensive list of vignettes and case studies which illustrate how to interpret and report the results of a variety of models: Bayesian, GAMs, Mixed-Effects, causal inference, etc.

\# Resources
[https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/marginaleffects/](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/vincentarelbundock.github.io/marginaleffects/__;!!BZ50a36bapWJ!olUQhCvdpZCzalqJC8AWnw-cALExxl0pSfA99ot45n7ZlSaiVa4zv0PLvVMPq8OCoihUGe5KVMoezG8INYk7uMGzoLTp$)
[http://arelbundock.com](https://urldefense.com/v3/__http:/arelbundock.com__;!!BZ50a36bapWJ!olUQhCvdpZCzalqJC8AWnw-cALExxl0pSfA99ot45n7ZlSaiVa4zv0PLvVMPq8OCoihUGe5KVMoezG8INYk7uHzenVH9$)

\# Bio
Vincent Arel-Bundock is an Associate Professor of Political Science at the UniversitÃ© de MontrÃ©al, where he teaches research methods and political economy. He uploaded his first R package to CRAN in 2009. 13 years later, he is still fielding support emails and bug reports.

This event is Cross-posted from SoCal RUG: I fit a model... now what?
RSVP at: [https://www.meetup.com/socal-rug/events/287436989/](https://www.meetup.com/socal-rug/events/287436989/)

title: R Ladies Bogor 14th meet up: Mixture Modelling in R with case study
description:
Halo rekan-rekan semua,

Weekend ini rencananya kita akan mengadakan R Ladies Bogor 14th Meet Up!

Pemateri kita kali ini adalah **Kezia Olive** yang sedang melanjutkan studinya di **Faculty of Educational Sciences, di University of Helsinki**. Tema yang akan disampaikan juga seru sekali, tentang **"Uncovering gender difference through latent profile (mixture modelling) in R"**.

Seperti biasa, kegiatan akan dilaksanakan secara online di hari **Sabtu, 20 Agustus 2022 (14.00-16.00 WIB)**

Untuk link registrasinya bisa mengisi di sini (https://bit.ly/3wbjRCd ), dan link zoomnya akan dikirimkan melalui email rekan-rekan. Sampai bertemu semuanya!

title: R-Ladies Book Club
description:
For our August book club, we'll be discussing "Queer Data : Using Gender, Sex and Sexuality Data for Action" by Dr. Kevin Guyan. The New York Public Library has copies of this book.

***

This event will be in person at the Great Hill in Central Park. Enter at Central Park West and 106th. Bring a blanket if you have one! We will be sitting on the grass.

In case of rain, this event will be held over zoom and the link and password will be shared the morning of the event.

***

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: August BookClub - ISLR Tidymodels Lab
description:
R-Ladies Philly is launching a series of bookclub meetups to promote community-supported learning experiences. The nominated book for this year is [An Introduction to Statistical Learning (ISLR)](https://www.statlearning.com/). To differentiate our group from the on-going bookclub at [The R4DS Online Learning Community](https://r4ds.github.io/bookclub-islr/), we will focus on application for [tidymodels](https://www.tidymodels.org/) using the [ISLR-tidymodels labs](https://emilhvitfeldt.github.io/ISLR-tidymodels-labs/index.html) that were kindly authored by Emil Hvitfeldt.
Everyone is welcomed to participate in the bookclub. To enhance the learning experience, there will be volunteers to lead the bookclub at each monthly meetup. The volunteers will give an 20 \~ 30 minutes summary presentation on the chapter. The presentation format will either be overview of the chapter, applying the chapter content to a mini-data project, or another preferred format. It will be followed with community-driven Q&A.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:10 Join Online
6:10 - 6:20 Welcome and Annoucement
6:20 - 6:50 Chapter 4 Classification ()
6:50 - 7:20 Chapter 5 Resampling Methods (Kelsey Keith)
7:25 - 7:55 Chapter 6 Linear Model Selection and Regularization (Chun Su)

**If you are interested in volunteering to lead bookclub, please sign up [here](https://tinyurl.com/rladies-bookclub)**

title: Making and publishing your first R package *** Virtual attendance***
description:
Most of us have experience in using R to clean our data, run a few functions from another package, and produce a publishable, reproducible result. However, making the leap from running a few lines of code, to writing our own functions, to then finally bundling and publishing our own R package can be daunting. This R workshop is intended for intermediate-level R users who wish to make the leap from R user to R contributor, though all skill levels are welcome. This tutorial will focus on using the {devtools}, {usethis}, and {pkgdown} packages to help build your very own R package from scratch. The slideshow for the presentation can be found on Github here: [https://github.com/popovs/r-pkg-slides](https://github.com/popovs/r-pkg-slides)
Sarah Popov, MSc is a marine ecologist with a strong data management background who cares about great design. Sarah's current research interests lie in theoretical ecology, exploration of marine food webs, and the importance of large storm events in shaping marine communities. Sarah also loves helping other lab groups get a handle on monstrous amounts of data and working with databases. If you have any active research or data management opportunities you think Sarah would be a good fit for, please reach out to inquire about consulting. Sarah is based in Vancouver, Canada.
https://www.sarahpopov.com/

title: From Excel to R
description:
Why would you use R over Excel?
R and Excel are beneficial in different ways. Excel starts off easier to learn and is frequently cited as the go-to program for reporting, thanks to its speed and efficiency. **R is designed to handle larger data sets, to be reproducible, and to create more detailed visualizations.**
We can find out more from our speaker Yanina.

Our speaker Yanina Bellini Saibene is part of the R-Ladies Global team, is part of R-Ladies Santa Rosa chapter in La Pampa, Argentina and is the founder of LatinR_conf, Latin American Conference on the Use of R in Research + Development. She is also part of the Research team in the National Institute of Agricultural Technology (INTA), https://app.scientist.com/providers/national-institute-of-agricultural-technology-inta.

title: Tracking gene expression changes in cancer using simple blood tests
description:
Hello everyone! We are excited to host our July event online. Looking forward to seeing you all!

Dineika is a senior postdoctoral fellow at the Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre where she leads a bioinformatics team within the Molecular Biomarkers and Translational Genomics lab. Her current research revolves around circulating tumour DNA which can be captured from the bloodstream of cancer patients. These are fragmented pieces of DNA released from tumour cells which carry mutations, methylation and other alterations of the cancer genome. Therefore, a simple blood test gives us a window to study the cancer, offering a non-invasive alternative to often painful tumour biopsies. Dineika develops innovative methods to analyse circulating tumour DNA and use it as a non-invasive biomarker to detect the presence of cancer and track how tumours evolve and become resistant to therapy. Her ongoing passion is to translate these methodologies to the clinic under the mantra of â€˜bench to bedsideâ€™.

Circulating tumour DNA in the blood of cancer patients can be used to investigate somatic alterations such as mutations and copy number events of the cancer genome as well as epigenomic signatures such as methylation. However, the assays in clinical use cannot capture tumour gene expression even though we now know that tumours escape cancer therapy by changing their transcriptome as well as their genome. I will present a new method we have developed named SNIPER (Serial Non-Invasive Plasma gene Expression Reconstruction) that can be applied to serial blood tests to study how tumours change their gene expression as they evolve. I will discuss results from applying SNIPER to 180 blood samples across Breast cancer, Melanoma, Lung cancer and blood cancers and show how we have adapted tools such as limma and gProfiler for this non-standard data type.

title: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"
description:
Â¡Desde RLadies Bariloche les invitamos a continuar con el estudio en grupo del libro R para Ciencia de Datos (versiÃ³n traducida al espaÃ±ol de R for Data Science) de Hadley Wickham (el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes mÃ¡s!). El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ Â¡EstÃ¡ muy bueno!

â€¢ Nos juntaremos de forma virtual una vez cada 15 dÃ­as para avanzar con la lectura y comprensiÃ³n del libro y los scripts. Cada encuentro serÃ¡ guiado por uno o dos integrantes del grupo.

â€¢ En el segundo encuentro de julio discutiremos el capitulo nÃºmero 15 â€œ[Factores](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/factores.html)â€, secciones 15.1 hasta 15.3 inclusive, el cual serÃ¡ guiado por Jan (Elle), Dr. en Ciencias de la ComputaciÃ³n y ademÃ¡s es coorganizadore de R-Ladies Mendoza.
Es necesario llegar a la reuniÃ³n con el capÃ­tulo previamente leÃ­do y trabajado.

â€¢ Â¡Importante! Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

â€¢ Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aÃºn no se sumaron, van a recibir mÃ¡s adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que serÃ¡ nuestra principal vÃ­a de comunicaciÃ³n. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.

â€¢ Interesadxs en guiar el prÃ³ximo capÃ­tulo nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo bariloche@rladies.org. Cuanto antes, mejor.

â€¢ A partir del primer encuentro, cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionarÃ¡. Por ejemplo, sortearÃ¡ o decidirÃ¡ quiÃ©n guiarÃ¡ el siguiente capÃ­tulo, si verÃ¡n un capÃ­tulo, medio capÃ­tulo o dos capÃ­tulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarÃ¡n lo que se viÃ³ en el capÃ­tulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir informaciÃ³n en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el cÃ³digo de conducta que encontrarÃ¡n en la pÃ¡gina.

Para asistir al meetup, les recomendamos poseer una cuenta de google (en el caso de que utilicemos google meet) e intalar zoom. Se recomienda tener conocimientos bÃ¡sicos de R.

Â¡ATENCIÃ“N! por cuestiones de seguridad virtual, el enlace a la reuniÃ³n se enviarÃ¡ unos minutos antes de la misma. Por ello les pedimos que
estÃ©n alertas al correo.

title: R-Ladies Reception at rstudio::conf(2022)
description:
The R-Ladies Birds of a Feather reception at RStudio Conference is the last event of RStudio conference, and it is open to all R-Ladies, not just conference attendees.

Come mix and mingle with R-Ladies from DC and all over the world! There will be light refreshments. (And hex stickers!)

Parking is available onsite for $10.

The reception will be held in the Gaylord National Resort & Convention Center, in room Maryland A+123. (Room is subject to change.)

This event is sponsored by RStudio.

Important Note: Because this is an in-person event sponsored by RStudio at their conference, their [COVID-19](https://www.rstudio.com/conference/2022/2022-conf-code-of-conduct/#covid19) and [Code of Conduct](https://www.rstudio.com/conference/2022/2022-conf-code-of-conduct) policies must be followed by all attendees. The COVID-19 policy is posted below for your reference.

title: RStudio Conference 2022 Watch party
description:
Need motivation? Virtual lunch buddies? Or just a group of people to upvote your question? Come watch the live stream of the RStudio conference with us over lunch hour! You can check out the schedule here: https://www.rstudio.com/conference/2022/schedule/

Date and time: July 27, 2022 at 11:30am
Webinar link: RSVP to view the link (password follows \`?pwd=\` in the link)
If you have trouble getting into the meeting, please message Jasmine

See you there!

Yuka, Jasmine and Lisa

**IMPORTANT**\*\*

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready
2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
3. Who is allowed to attend?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

title: PyLadies + R-Ladies â€” Bringing the communities together
description:
We are excited to host an event that shows us how to combine both R and Python and build a bridge across two fantastic communities! ğŸ’œ

Our fantastic speakers Rhian Davies and Deena Gergis will talk about their experiences when working bilingually with both R and Python.
To learn more about both languages, we will also have a quiz which also comes with great prizes (sponsored by [Aiven](https://twitter.com/aiven_io)) ğŸ¥³

**âœ¨ A Tale of Two Languages âœ¨**
In this talk, Rhian will share stories how [Jumping Rivers](https://www.jumpingrivers.com/) develop in both R and Python - often in the same project.
Rhian will share how they write all of their Python training materials in R Markdown, and how they built the [Diffify](https://diffify.com/) tool to analyze R packages in both Python and R.
Rhian will also talk a little about the challenges and opportunities they have working within a bilingual team at Jumping Rivers.

**About Rhian Davies**
[Rhian](https://twitter.com/statsrhian) loves using statistics to help people make data driven decisions. As a data scientist at Jumping Rivers, she has worked closely with varied domain experts including physicists, psychologists, game designers and engineers.

**âœ¨ MLflow - a better way to track your models** **âœ¨**
In a perfect world, you would get clean data that you will feed into a single machine learning model and voila, done. But fortunately, reality is much more interesting than a perfect world. A well-performing ML model will only be ready after a bunch of trials. You will have to try different algorithms along with a bunch of hyper parameters, different variants of your training data, and maybe even different variants of your target variable. This complex mix and match makes the challenge a fun one, but also messy to track. Solution? MLflow to the rescue.

**About Deena Gergis**
[Deena](https://www.linkedin.com/in/deena-gergis/) is an award-winning AI expert whose ultimate purpose is to offer a better quality of life to people using AI. During the first half of her career in academia and research, Deena researched Machine Learning algorithms to diagnose and treat various types of cancer. And during the second half of her career in industry, Deena has successfully helped multiple German and multi-national companies to apply Machine Learning to develop cutting-edge products in a wide variety of verticals including sales, marketing, pricing, finance and industry 4.0. Deena is currently a Lead Data Scientist at Bayer. In her current role, she combines the best from academia and industry to develop AI products that will ultimately help people live a healthier life.

To stay up-to-date with our future events, make sure to also follow us on Twitter ([@RLadies_Cologne](https://twitter.com/rladies_cologne), [@PyLadiesMunich](https://twitter.com/pyladiesmunich), and [@PyLadiesTunis](https://twitter.com/pyladiestunis)) ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»

description:

title: Using R with Excel Tutorial & useR! 2022 Highlights
description:
***Please RSVP via both (1) this MeetUp event's page and (2) the Google Form linked on the right.***

Join us Tuesday, July 19, for an interactive, hands-on tutorial on using R with Excel, a summary of highlights from useR! 2022, and networking.

**Schedule**
Tuesday, July 19, 6:30-8:30 pm (Pacific)
6:30 - Welcome
6:35 - Announcements
6:40 - Using R with Excel Tutorial
7:40 - Highlights from useR! 2022
8:00 - Networking
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

**Using R with Excel**
Alyssa Columbus will present an introduction to using R with Excel. This tutorial will include the following:

* Steps to import and export Excel workbooks with R
* Techniques to conduct common Excel data analyses in R, including visualizations and row/column calculations
* Additional resources to learn more about R and Excel interactivity in the future
* Several opportunities to ask questions

Link to Materials: [https://github.com/acolum/r-ladies-irvine-using-r-with-excel](https://github.com/acolum/r-ladies-irvine-using-r-with-excel)

**Highlights from useR! 2022**
Madeline Bauer, PhD will present the new and exciting R developments and packages introduced at this year's useR! Conference.

title: July BookClub - ISLR Tidymodels Lab
description:
R-Ladies Philly is launching a series of bookclub meetups to promote community-supported learning experiences. The nominated book for this year is [An Introduction to Statistical Learning (ISLR)](https://www.statlearning.com/). To differentiate our group from the on-going bookclub at [The R4DS Online Learning Community](https://r4ds.github.io/bookclub-islr/), we will focus on application for [tidymodels](https://www.tidymodels.org/) using the [ISLR-tidymodels labs](https://emilhvitfeldt.github.io/ISLR-tidymodels-labs/index.html) that were kindly authored by Emil Hvitfeldt.

Everyone is welcomed to participate in the bookclub. To enhance the learning experience, there will be volunteers to lead the bookclub at each monthly meetup. The volunteers will give an 20 \~ 30 minutes summary presentation on the chapter. The presentation format will either be overview of the chapter, applying the chapter content to a mini-data project, or another preferred format. It will be followed with community-driven Q&A.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:10 Join Online
6:10 - 7:00 A gentle introduction to tidymodels workflow
7:05 - 7:30 Volunteer presentation on linear regression (chapter 3)
7:30 - 8:00 Community driven Q&A

**If you are interested in volunteering to lead bookclub, please sign up [here](https://tinyurl.com/rladies-bookclub)**

title: Expresiones regulares: encuentra patrones en tu texto con R
description:
Nos sumamos al grupo de estudio y lectura con RLadies Bariloche sobre el libro [R para ciencia de datos](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/), que es la versiÃ³n traducida al espaÃ±ol de [R for Data Science](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/) de Hadley Wickham, quien es el creador de Tidyverse y varios paquetes mÃ¡s.

En este encuentro Ana Laura Diedrichs, Ing. en Sistemas de InformaciÃ³n e Instructora Tidyverse certificada, nos guiarÃ¡ por [el capitulo nÃºmero 14 "Cadena de caracteres" , secciÃ³n 14.3- Herramientas.](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/cadenas-de-caracteres.html#herramientas)

En esta clase taller veremos funciones para manipular cadenas de caracteres en R de la librerÃ­a [stringr](https://stringr.tidyverse.org/), priorizando la enseÃ±anza y prÃ¡ctica de [expresiones regulares](https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expresi%C3%B3n_regular) para identificar patrones en textos y extraerlos.

Para realizar los ejercicios en tu propia computadora es necesario tener instalado: R, Rstudio, los paquetes tidyverse, datos, y guaguas, preferentemente en las Ãºltimas versiones.

Sino, durante el taller usaremos un proyecto de [RStudio Cloud](https://rstudio.cloud/) con todo lo necesario para trabajar. Te pedimos que previo al taller crees una cuenta gratuita ingresando a [rstudio.cloud/](https://rstudio.cloud/) y siguiendo las instrucciones para registrarte. Ten en cuenta que la cuenta gratuita tiene un lÃ­mite de uso de 15 horas por mes, te recomendamos no usar todas las horas antes del taller. De esta forma sÃ³lo necesitarÃ¡s tu navegador web y tu cuenta Rstudio Cloud para trabajar, sin necesidad de instalar nada en tu computadora.

* **Â¡Importante!** Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies Mendoza en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento ( material con el que trabajarÃ¡n, software que necesitarÃ¡n instalarse, cambios del evento, etc )
* Quienes se inscriban al meetup y si aÃºn no se sumaron, van a recibir mÃ¡s adelante un enlace para sumarse al espacio de trabajo de slack que es exclusivo para el estudio del libro y que serÃ¡ nuestra principal vÃ­a de comunicaciÃ³n. Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.
* Â¿ Quieres estudiar con nuestro grupo ? Postulante para dar una charla de alguna de las siguientes secciones o capÃ­tulos del libro. ContÃ¡ctanos a [mendoza@rladies.org](mailto:mendoza@rladies.org)

title: GRUPO 3. TALLER DE ESTUDIO LIBRO "R PARA CIENCIA DE DATOS"
description:

El libro es de libre acceso en https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/ Â¡EstÃ¡ muy bueno!

â€¢ En el primer encuentro de Julio seguiremos trabajando con el capitulo nÃºmero 14 "[Cadena de caracteres](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/cadenas-de-caracteres.html)" , secciÃ³n 14.3- [Herramientas](https://es.r4ds.hadley.nz/cadenas-de-caracteres.html#herramientas). Este encuentro serÃ¡ guiado por Ana Laura Diedrichs, Ing. en Sistemas de informaciÃ³n e instructora Tidyverse certificada.

Ni bien se inscriban en el meetup, entren a los ajustes de su perfil y verifiquen tener activas las notificaciones, no sÃ³lo del meetup en general, sino del grupo RLadies-BRC en particular (figuran abajo del todo en notificaciones por correo electrÃ³nico) para poder recibir luego el enlace para conectarse y otras notificaciones relacionadas al evento.

Si nunca lo usaron y/o necesitan ayuda para familiarizarse, escrÃ­bannos y les damos una orientaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida.

â€¢ Necesitamos uno o dos voluntarias o voluntarios para guiar el prÃ³ximo capÃ­tulo. Interesadxs nos lo pueden comunicar por el slack o al correo bariloche@rladies.org. Cuanto antes, mejor. En caso de que nadie se ofrezca, haremos un sorteo (con el comando sample() en R!!!).

â€¢ Cada grupo de trabajo se auto-gestionarÃ¡. Por ejemplo, sortearÃ¡ o decidirÃ¡ quiÃ©n guiarÃ¡ el siguiente capÃ­tulo, si verÃ¡n un capÃ­tulo, medio capÃ­tulo o dos capÃ­tulos (la propuesta general es ir despacio, lento pero sin tregua), si aplicarÃ¡n lo que se viÃ³ en el capÃ­tulo a otro set de datos etc. Contamos con el espacio de slack para consultarnos y compartir informaciÃ³n en cada grupo y entre grupos.

Al anotarse, les pedimos que primero lean y acepten el cÃ³digo de conducta que encontrarÃ¡n en la pÃ¡gina.

title: REMOTE: R Lightening Talks by R-Ladies
description:
!! Be mindful that only those participants that registered via Eventbrite (https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/remote-r-lightening-talks-by-r-ladies-tickets-379968444847) will receive the meetup Zoom link and will be able to join the event. Feel free to RVSP in the Meetup event page but also make sure you register on Eventbrite !!

Welcome to our first R-ladies London Meetup this year! We are back online with two exciting presentations!

Join us in our remote meetup to learn tips and new skills in R with these easily digestible 15-minute long lightning talks! Also, we're not going to give up on the tradition of after-talks socialising, which will take place in the breakout Zoom rooms. So make sure you have some snacks, drinks and some cool webcam background on (behind) you!

Meetup ProgRam
18:30 - Welcome to Rladies remote lightning talks!
18:40 - Hannah Frick: "Introducing the censored package"
19:00 - Emma Vestesson: "Making reproducible tables in R"
19:20-20:00 - Remote Socialising!

ABSTRACTS

Introducing the censored package - Hannah Frick
This talk introduces censored, a new tidymodels package for survival models. We will discuss how this package extends parsnip principles for censored regression and which models, engines, and prediction types are available.

Hannah Frick is a software engineer and statistician on the tidymodels team at RStudio. The tidymodels framework is a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. She holds a PhD in statistics and has worked in data science consultancy as well as interdisciplinary research at University College London in cooperation with Team GB Hockey.

Making reproducible tables in R - Emma Vestesson
Have you ever painstakingly copied results from your R console into a word or excel document? Creating your tables directly in R will save you time and improve the reproducibility of your analysis. This talk will cover how to easily create basic summary statistics and regression tables and how save them in different formats.

Emma Vestesson is a senior data analyst at the Health Foundation. She is also a PhD student at UCL and is currently spending at year at the Alan Turing Institute.

title: [ONLINE] Spatial Data Basics with sf in R (Part 3)
description:
By the end of the third of this two part series (this is the bonus part!), participants will be able to **apply** sf and tidyverse operations to wrangle and map real-world spatial data. This event will include some instruction but we'll also use breakout rooms to separate into smaller groups and try to practice what we learned in parts 1 and 2. We will assume that attendees are already familiar with the information covered in the part 1 and 2 on June 14 and June 28, 2022). The code and instruction materials from part 1 and 2 are available on GitHub here: [https://github.com/sheilasaia/sf-workshop-rladies](https://github.com/sheilasaia/sf-workshop-rladies).

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Agenda:
â€¢ 6:30pm - 6:45pm - Introductions
â€¢ 6:45pm - 7:50pm - Hands-on Workshop
â€¢ 7:50pm - 8:00pm - Wrap up

Who is this for?
This meetup is for beginners who have **no experience** programming in R (or another coding language); however, we will assume that attendees are already familiar with the information covered in the part 1 on June 14, 2022). We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

**We will be using web browser-based interactive coding notebooks for this workshop so no installation of R or RStudio is required.** These notebooks will ensure that everyone's code runs properly as there can be many tricky software dependency issues that pop up while doing spatial analysis work. Links to the coding notebooks will be provided at the start of the workshop. Folks are welcome to work without their web-browers, if they feel comfortable to do this independently.

Please contact Sheila at sheila@rladies.org at least 48 hours (or earlier) **before the event** if you have any questions.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the internet capabilities to run Zoom and your favorite web browser.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

title: Reproducible Research with R markdown
description:
"Reproducible Research with R Markdown"

Research is considered to be reproducible when the exact results can be reproduced if given access to the original data, software, or code. Reproducible research is sometimes known as reproducibility, reproducible statistical analysis, reproducible data analysis, reproducible reporting, and literate programming.

Jenine K. Harris, PhD, https://twitter.com/jenineharris is a Professor teaching biostatistics courses in the public health program at the George Warren Brown School of Social Work at Washington University in St. Louis in Missouri, United States. Her recent research interests focus on increasing diversity in data science and improving the quality of research in public health by using reproducible research practices throughout the research process. Jenine's 2020 book, Statistics with R: Solving Problems Using Real-World Data, is an introductory statistics textbook published by Sage. The book combines statistical concepts with R coding and includes representation of women throughout as both characters and as authors of resources. Each chapter addresses a different social problem using a real-world data set. She is also the co-founder and current organizer of R-Ladies St. Louis,https://twitter.com/RLadiesSTL a local chapter of the R-Ladies Global organization that has the mission of increasing gender diversity in the R community.

title: Creating your own interactive tutorials with `learnr`
description:
You can consider this a meta workshop. I will be giving a quick intro to the package 'learnr' and then go through the steps to get tutorials set up inside an R package, for use when giving workshops or organizing courses. Meetup will be recorded and files will be uploaded to github after the event.

UPDATE: I am so sorry everyone! Scheduling conflicts and family dynamics have been tough lately. Promise, this is the last change! :D

title: Shiny Dashboards: Pride Edition ğŸŒˆ
description:
'Mastering Shiny' takes time and practice! Join R-Ladies Freiburg for an evening of data wrangling, plotting, and ultimately putting it all together into your own Pride-themed data dashboard.

For this workshop, we'll use a great dataset on "rainbow capitalism" from Tidy Tuesday and Data for Progress:
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2022/2022-06-07

Description from Data for Progress, quoted by TT:
Each year, hundreds of corporations around the country participate in Pride, an annual celebration of the LGBTQ+ communityâ€™s history and progress. They present themselves as LGBTQ+ allies, but new research from Data for Progress finds that in between their yearly parade appearances, dozens of these corporations are giving to state politicians behind some of the most bigoted and harmful policies in over a decade.

We'll take a look at the data, wrangle it into the right format, find a fitting graph, and make the whole thing into an interactive plot in a Shiny dashboard -- all with plenty of chances to try things on your own (or watch some live coding if you prefer!)

If you're just getting started with Shiny, we recommend checking out the recordings of our previous workshops on the topic:
Basics incl. input and output - https://youtu.be/gk73bLmteP0
Basic plots - https://youtu.be/Bb5Xol1oU_I
Eurovision example - https://youtu.be/UGTTqhxaICU

title: Hands on ggplot2 package
description:
Join Us at this wonderful event.
More about the speaker:
Jenine K. Harris earned her doctorate in public health studies and biostatistics from Saint Louis University School of Public Health in 2008. Currently, she teaches biostatistics courses as an Associate Professor in the Brown School public health program at Washington University in St. Louis. In 2013, she authored An Introduction to Exponential Random Graph Modeling, which was published in Sageâ€™s Quantitative Applications in the Social Sciences series and is accompanied by the ergmharris R package available on the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN). She is an author of more than 80 peer-reviewed publications and developed and published the odds.n.ends R package available on the CRAN. She is the leader of R-Ladies St. Louis, which she co-founded with Chelsea West in 2017 (@rladiesstl). R-Ladies St. Louis is a local chapter of R-Ladies Global (@rladiesglobal), an organization devoted to promoting gender diversity in the R community. Her recent research interests focus on improving the quality of research in public health by using reproducible research practices throughout the research process.

title: Recovery mixeR powered by Budapest Users of R Network
description:
Sziasztok!

SzeretnÃ©nk mindenkit meginvitÃ¡lni a [Budapest Users of R Network](https://www.meetup.com/budapest-users-of-r-network/) meetupjÃ¡ra, jÃºnius 29, szerda 18:00-ra.

A meetup leÃ­rÃ¡sÃ¡t alÃ¡bb talÃ¡ljÃ¡tok, az esemÃ©ny linkjÃ©t pedig [itt](https://www.meetup.com/Budapest-Users-of-R-Network/events/286460893/):

Current list of planned talks:

* **Ãgoston Reguly (CEU): Introducing students to data analysis with R**

I have put together an R coding lecture at CEU to introduce students to coding with R. Now it is officially available at github: https://github.com/gabors-data-analysis/da-coding-rstats I would love to share the logic behind the course and would be curious about feedbacks

* **Berta BÃ¶jte (Starschema): Q-method - A special kind of Factor Analysis**

During my thesis I conducted an analytical study of an e-learning system using the so called Q-method. It's a special case for factor analysis that helps identify opinions about a topic. The language of the analysis was R, building on data.table and the qmethod package, which is created especially to support these kind of analysis. In my talk I would like to briefly introduce this analytical method and how the mentioned R package made it really easy to execute.

* **Gergely Daroczi (Rx Studio Inc): Internationalization of R packages**

Quick demo on r18r (R package to extract terms to be translated from R packages and manage translations along with translator comments) and Weblate (web frontend to translate PO files).

* **Kristof Kelemen: ggprism**

I was challenged recently with a task to produce figures similar to GraphPad Prism output and stumbled upon ggprism package. While this might sound too specific, there is some merit to its functions for all those who want to produce nice-looking graphs with high information content.

* **DÃ©nes TÃ³th: R in Visual Studio Code**

In the R world, RStudio IDE is the most beloved development environment tool, whereas outside of it, it is Visual Studio Code which takes the lead. In this talk I will present its R extension (vscode-R) and why (and when) you should consider to switch to it.

After a long break, we are rebooting the R meetup and I am really looking forward to meeting you all again in person!

Instead of hosting a longer technical talk, we decided to have multiple shorter talks this time, where any member of the community can share about an R package, an R-based project, or simply about their passion for R.

If interested in giving a 5 mins talk (freestyle, either in Hungarian or English), please fill out this form: [https://forms.gle/gMXypczqZoLbVaYD7](https://forms.gle/gMXypczqZoLbVaYD7)

If not willing to speak this time -- no worries, please join us for the talks and the networking event afterwards.

This meetup is kindly hosted at and sponsored by CEU. Food (pogacsa) and drinks (beer, wine, mineral water) will be served onsite after the talks, and we will also make table reservations in a nearby pub after 8.30 pm.

title: Current state and prospects of R-packages for the design of experiments
description:
This event is hosted by the Canberra Branch is the Statistical Society of Australia. RLadies Canberra members are invited to attend in-person at [Allan Barton Forum](https://goo.gl/maps/NxtbGw1kie3oGmJK7), The Australian National University, or by the online stream via Zoom.

The presenter, Dr. Emi Tanaka, is a lecturer in statistics at Monash University whose primary interest is to develop impactful statistical methods and tools that can readily be used by practitioners. Her research area includes data visualisation, mixed models and experimental designs, motivated primarily by problems in bioinformatics and agricultural sciences.

In this presentation, Emi will give an overview about the current state and prospects of R-packages for the design of experiments. She will also introduce an object-oriented programming system, called the grammar of experimental designs, that is designed to specify experimental designs encapsulated in a cognitive framework and implemented as the edibble R-package.

title: Using Data Science to Respond to Natural Disasters
description:
**What are we going to learn?**

The recent floods in Brisbane last March inundated 13,000 homes inflicting a heavy toll on lives and livelihoods. Half a year's worth of rain fell in three days. The lack of warning to residents inspired Drs Kate Saunders and Kate Helmstedt (QUT) to organise a [Rapid Response Hackathon](https://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/rapid-response-hackathon-to-the-recent-floods-tickets-290258299387?keep_tld=1) with QUT's [Applied Mathematical Ecology Group](https://qutameg.wordpress.com/) and [Centre for Data Science](https://research.qut.edu.au/qutcds/) to address the question - how can broad scale weather warning systems be translated into on-the-ground, local impacts for communities? Kate will give an introduction as to how data science is useful for natural disaster management and then we will hear from Hackathon teams.

**Who is going to present?**

Dr Kate Saunders, Lecturer in Optimal Ecological Management, and teams for the hackathon, or "Digitial Mud Army," will be presenting the following work-in-progress topics:

* Past observations - Dr Ben Fitzpatrick
* Social media scraping - Tace Stewart, Lanxi Li
* Vulnerability Index - Dr Catherine Kim
* Road Closures - Peter Tarbit
* Flood Extent - Charlotte Patterson

**When are we meeting?**
***The presentation will start at 5:00 pm (AEST)***

The presentation will run for approximately an hour with time for questions and mingling at the Ship Inn/Brisbane Brew Co etc!

**Where are we meeting?**

* This talk will be held via at [QUT Gardens Point P-413](https://goo.gl/maps/gT2hNCCVoxCAr1Nh9) and on Zoom [https://qut.zoom.us/j/85460132436?pwd=a2FpQk5XdE5iTGhPZ1J6aGJBZmFMZz09](https://qut.zoom.us/j/85460132436?pwd=a2FpQk5XdE5iTGhPZ1J6aGJBZmFMZz09)

We look forward to seeing you there!

R-Ladies Brisbane

***

Photos, Films and all other media/recordings: Photographs and/or video/other media will be taken at events held by this community. By taking part in an R-Ladies Brisbane event you grant the community organisers full rights to use the images resulting from the photography/video filming/media, and any reproductions or adaptations of the images for publicity, fund-raising or other purposes to help achieve the communityâ€™s aims. This might include (but is not limited to), the right to use them in their printed and online publicity, social media, press releases and funding applications. If you do not wish to be recorded in these media please inform a community organiser.

Code of Conduct: R-Ladies Brisbane is dedicated to providing a welcoming and harassment-free event experience for everyone, regardless of gender, gender identity and expression, age, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, ethnicity, or religion (or lack thereof). We do not tolerate harassment of event participants in any form, for any event venue, including talks, workshops, parties, Twitter and other online media.

Community Policies: Please note, cis men are welcome to join our meetups when they come as a guest of a woman participant or they bring a woman with them. We highly encourage speakers and teachers at R-Ladies Brisbane events to be of minority genders.

Find us on Twitter @rladiesbrisbane and https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_brisbane for more information, news, presentations and code!

title: Virtual Code-laboration: #TidyTuesday (RSVP Link in Description)
description:
Want to come code and learn with us? For Juneâ€™s NYC R-ladies meetup, we are planning a #TidyTuesday code-laboration event! This event will be held online via Zoom. Please register via the Google Form below:

[https://forms.gle/RN5FkyEaRGnLbxx37](https://forms.gle/RN5FkyEaRGnLbxx37)

**The zoom link will be emailed ONLY to those who register in advance via the form above the morning of the event.**

**â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”**

**We ask participants to pick a [TidyTuesday dataset](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2022) from the month of May or June and create (or attempt to create!) a visualization of the dataset before the meetup. At the meetup, participants will have the opportunity to:**

**Share something you learned in making the TidyTuesday**

* Did you learn a new function in the process?
* Did you discover a new package?
* Did you learn something new with the data you explored?

**Share your process or tips for making the TidyTuesday**

* What TidyTuesday tips do you have?

**Share something you struggled with**

* What is a barrier you ran into while trying to create your TidyTuesday? We will work together to answer questions people ran into

**Share your visualization!**

* We will showcase the visualizations and works-in-progress we made with each other!

Even if you donâ€™t have time to work on a #TidyTuesday before the meetup, **we hope you will still join us to collaboratively learn and code with each other!**

**â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”**

**Links and Resources:**

**What is #TidyTuesday?**

* TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project hosted by the R for Data Science community. Every Tuesday a new dataset is posted, and everyone is invited to explore and visualize the data. â€œThe intent of Tidy Tuesday is to provide a safe and supportive forum for individuals to practice their wrangling and data visualization skillsâ€ (TidyTuesday repository on GitHub [https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday)).

**How can I see what other people have created?**

* People will often post their final TidyTuesday creations on twitter with the [#TidyTuesday](https://twitter.com/search?q=tidytuesday&src=typed_query&f=live) hashtag.

title: [ONLINE] Spatial Data Basics with sf in R (Part 2)
description:
By the end of the second of this two part series (first part was on June 14, 2022), participants will be able to **explain** different types of spatial operations using the sf package in R and **apply** sf and tidyverse operations to wrangle and map real-world spatial data. We will assume that attendees are already familiar with the information covered in the part 1 on June 14, 2022).

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them (i.e., attend through the "guest" function on their host's RSVP, not as a separate RSVP). This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please contact the event organizer.

Agenda:
â€¢ 6:30pm - 6:45pm - Introductions
â€¢ 6:45pm - 7:50pm - Hands-on Workshop
â€¢ 7:50pm - 8:00pm - Wrap up

Who is this for?
This meetup is for beginners who have **no experience** programming in R (or another coding language); however, we will assume that attendees are already familiar with the information covered in the part 1 on June 14, 2022). We will use live coding demonstrations and participates will actively engage with the instructor throughout the workshop.

**We will be using web browser-based interactive coding notebooks for this workshop so no installation of R or RStudio is required.** These notebooks will ensure that everyone's code runs properly as there can be many tricky software dependency issues that pop up while doing spatial analysis work. Links to the coding notebooks will be provided at the start of the workshop. Folks are welcome to work without their web-browers, if they feel comfortable to do this independently.

Please contact Sheila at sheila@rladies.org at least 48 hours (or earlier) **before the event** if you have any questions.

What should I bring?
Please login to Zoom using a laptop or computer with the internet capabilities to run Zoom and your favorite web browser.

Where will it take place?
Please join us online via Zoom. A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

title: Using Git and Github in RStudio: A Hands-on Session
description:
Join us after Day 2 of the [useR! 2022](https://user2022.r-project.org/) conference!

This meetup event is meant for people new to git and GitHub but comfortable in RStudio.

* Lisa will show you how to connect git and GitHub to your projects, mostly using tools available directly within the RStudio IDE.
* Youâ€™ll be using version control by the end of the session
* Youâ€™ll never have to name something final_version_i_promise.Rmd ever again!
* It is helpful to have the following R packages installed beforehand: {[usethis](https://usethis.r-lib.org/)}, {[credentials](https://docs.ropensci.org/credentials/)}, {[gert](https://docs.ropensci.org/gert/)}, and {[gh](https://gh.r-lib.org/)}.
* If you are a Mac user, made sure to have [Xcode](https://developer.apple.com/xcode/) installed.

Speaker Bio: Dr. Lisa Lendway is an avid R user and has been using it in a variety of ways since 2003. She recently changed careers and is working as a Data Scientist for Blue Cross Blue Shield of MN. Prior to that she taught Statistics and Data Science at Macalester College. Outside of being a nerd, Lisa enjoys biking and doing house projects with her spouse, spending time with her two kids, and tending her urban garden.

title: R Users ANU launch
description: RLadies Canberra members who are also members of the ANU community are invited to attend this social morning tea hosted by ANU's network for early career academics, NECTAR, and the Statistical Support Network, SSN. Join us for this opportunity for ANU peers working in R to connect across boundaries. Women and men who are curious about R can come and ask questions about what this software is good for and how it compares. Guest speakers will give short presentations about how they have utilised R to solve research challenges. ANU will be launching a Teams site for R users. RLadies Canberra organisers will be on hand to meet ANU-based RLadies, register new members, and discuss plans for the next 18 months.

title: Data Hangout
description:
Data science can be intimidating. Especially so, when you are first embarking on your data adventure. Which tool to learn â€“ R or Python? What statistical methods to learn? What are typical data problems you need to be familiar with? What techniques to focus on? Which statistical method is applicable to my problem? These are some of the many questions you will begin to answer as you begin your journey.

**Data Hangout** is open access series of meetup workshops and discussions for people already working with data, or are just simply curious about what all the fuss is about. Data Hangout provides space for meaningful conversations or informal chats for data practitioners or those who are aspiring to be. Our motivation is to put ideas into action through the delivery of hands-on workshops.

Irrespective of whether youâ€™re already a data scientist or data enthusiast, our **Data Hangouts** are here to inform, motivate and equip you to use data as part of your everyday language. In turn, this will empower you to make data more integral to your daily working practices and be more prolific, regardless of your educational background and profession.

Together we share learning from both successful and challenging experiences to assemble and to deepen our collective data science knowledge. We build positive and active learning communities of data specialists with a diverse range of experiences and perspectives.
We discuss the skills and tools needed to get to grips with typical data science projects, illustrated by addressing the tasks required in formulating small case studies. We exchange ideas on how we consider data exploration and statistical modelling and the best ways of communicating the results with the target audience.

We do this by working through the open access material [DiSCDOWN](https://discdown.org), an online learning material platform developed at the [UniversitÃ¤t Innsbruck](https://www.uibk.ac.at/en/) using [R](https://www.r-project.org) and [Python](https://www.python.org).

In this month's **Data Hangout** we'll reserve 1st 45 minutes 17:00-17:45 for an '**R Clinic for beginners**' to assist with learning R syntax and troubleshooting some general programming questions. We will follow up our meeting with [DiSCDOWN](https://discdown.org) **workshop** 17:50:19:00 and a '**Presentation**' by [Nikola Panajotov](https://www.linkedin.com/in/npanajotov/) 19:00-19:30.

**The Schedule:**

* **16:50** Doors open and refreshments
* **17:00** **R Clinic for beginners**
* **17:45** Welcome break to all
* **17:50** **DiscDown:: Data Analytics:** Chapter 3 and maybe 4
* **19:00** **Presentation**: **Betting shops constellations** by [Nikola Panajotov](https://www.linkedin.com/in/npanajotov/)
How much betting shops in Belgrade are breaking the â€œGames of Chance Law?"
Using open data and by creating effective visualisation [Nikola](https://www.linkedin.com/in/npanajotov/) will show us are there betting shops in Belgrade that are breaking the law of being located within the minimum distance from the educational institutions required by the Serbian law.
Hereâ€™s a teaser: [https://maariaah.github.io/betting-shops-constellations/](https://maariaah.github.io/betting-shops-constellations/)
* **19:30** **Hang around**: a chance to chat
* **20:00** **The End**

We would love you to come and join us, bring a friend or two and share your thoughts and experiences when working on your every-day DS projects.

All welcome! We are looking forward to seeing youâ€¦

ps. please make sure you have read the code of conduct from our website: [https://sisteranalyst.org/coc](https://sisteranalyst.org/coc)

Thanks to [ICT HUB](https://www.icthub.rs/) for providing the venue and making this event possible.

title: Why R for legal backgrounds?
description:
**This is will be an interactive session where participants who have no background in R are strongly encouraged to attend and participants with backgrounds in R, but no legal background, are also strongly encouraged to attend.**

The presenter will share an ongoing project currently underway during a mentorship through Open Life Sciences (OLS). The project aims to create an open educational resource demonstrating the â€œwhyâ€ for people from legal backgrounds who might want to learn R. It is partly a case for open and reproducible research in a field that does not typically use R and quantitative methods. The project also involves creating different data sets derived from commonly used legal sources that law students or graduates would be familiar with and incorporating them into a single platform with a few examples of practical use and application as well as code.

**This event is a joint meeting between R-Ladies Dammam and R-Ladies Johannesburg, you can register on either page.**

We will design this session as a mix of demo, silent reflections and group discussions to bring diverse perspectives into the conversation. We will use a shared document for collaborative notetaking and capturing feedback and learnings also from those who cannot or prefer not to speak during the session.

**WHO is this for?**

* Individuals who have no background in R.
* Individuals who background in R, but no legal background.
* Both beginners and experienced R users are welcome to join!

**AGENDA**
5:30â€“6:00 pm Talk by Biandri Joubert
6:00â€“6:20 pm Breakout rooms
6:20â€“6:30 pm Discussion and wrap up

**The Speaker:**
Biandri is a researcher in the field of international trade law and has recently submitted her PhD thesis for marking. She will defend her thesis later in the year. She started her research with a purely legal (doctrinal) research background before transitioning to a mixed methodology PhD research project which included a content analysis using R programming. The difficulty in finding resources that were relatable to a legal academic background prompted the design of her Open Life Sciences (OLS) project. She is currently based in Johannesburg where she conducts both academic research and research/consulting in the private sector. When not writing/researching, she is most likely fly fishing or talking about fly fishing.

**Place: Zoom- https://zoom.us/download - The event will not be recorded.**
We will send you the Zoom link & the passcode via email a few hours before the meetup. Please check out your email later.
We look forward to welcoming you!

**If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us :**
#LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/r-ladies-saudi-arabia-dammam/
#Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-dammam/
#Twitter: https://twitter.com/RLadiesDammam
