title: Behind the scenes of visual journalism
description:
For our March event, we are excited to host Will Chase, who will be discussing data visualization and visual journalism.

This event will be hosted over Zoom. The link will be emailed to those who are registered, as well as posted on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:50: Behind the scenes of visual journalism
7:50-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

Abstract:
In this talk, I'll take you behind the scenes of how visual journalism works on the day to day. I'll talk about the tools we use, the challenges and rewards of journalism, and show the process of developing a visual story. I'll also discuss my own journey of being self-taught in data visualization and going from academia, to business, to journalism.

Bio:
Will is a developer, designer, journalist, and artist. He uses his background as a researcher to better understand the world through data and he shares those insights by designing and coding visual essays. Will has done dataviz in academia, business, freelance, and he currently works at Axios as a visual journalist. He also likes to make experimental stuff for the web and generative art.

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. For questions regarding accessibility, please email us at nyc@[rladies.org](http://rladies.org/).

title: IamRemarkable workshop
description:
#IamRemarkable is a Google initiative empowering women and underrepresented groups to speak openly about their accomplishments in the workplace and beyond, thereby breaking modesty norms and glass ceilings.

In this interactive session, you will participate in group discussions and exercises to develop the confidence and skills to promote yourself effectively.

During the #IamRemarkable workshop we will:
â— Share data and research regarding self-promotion and unconscious bias
â— Go through the main exercise to help you articulate your achievements and practice self-promotion

Important notes:
In order to create a safe environment, the event wonâ€™t be recorded.

Speaker
Giovanna Reggina Galleno Malaga \| Soft Skills Trainer & Data Analyst

She graduated in International Business Administration and Science & Technology from San Ignacio de Loyola University (Peru). She was part of the team of facilitators that trained more than 100k Peruvian women entrepreneurs in the Program "Women in Business" sponsored by The Inter-American Development Bank and The Australian Government. In addition, she was part of Google European Developer Relations, where working as Community Manager/Builder she â€œfell in love with dataâ€, and she decided to switch her career to become a Data Analyst. Currently, she is a co-organizer of the Machine Learning Milan community, the host of The Soft Skills Show on Youtube, and since 2019 sheâ€™s been a facilitator of the #IamRemarkable workshop.

**Ps. If for some reason you canâ€™t make it, please cancel your booking to give the opportunity to another member. Thank you for the collaboration.**

title: Speed up your spreadsheet reports with R
description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about Speed up your spreadsheet reports with R .
Date/Time: Wednesday, March, 16th 2022 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom
â–¶ï¸ Invited trainer: Larry Lathrop
â–¶ï¸ About Larry Lathrop:
Larry Lathrop is just a dad of 5 who loves data almost as much as he loves his family and their slobbery St Bernard. Larry is the head of analytics for OWLLytics with a passion for data visualizations. Larry enjoys traveling the world and currently lives in Valencia Spain.

Linkedin : https://www.linkedin.com/in/larry-lathrop/

â–¶ï¸ About the talk:

Love them or hate them, reports can take a long time to create. Instead of spending most of your time creating your reports, just streamline the process. Let's use R to tackle this problem! Don't worry, if your audience lives and swears by a spreadsheet, you can still use R. In this talk, we will demonstrate a simple and easy way you can use R to automate most of your reports. After implementing these simple techniques, you will be able to spend more time changing the world and less time on reports. Or if you prefer (like myself) spend more time savoring your coffee.

Make sure to join us!
In order to attend the event, please fill out this form ğŸ‘‰
https://tinyurl.com/3er6mrbt

We will send you the zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.
We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Keeping track of your R code: Version control with Git, GitHub and RStudio
description:
**\*BSL-English interpretation provided\***
SPEAKER
This online workshop will be led by Freya Watkins (she/her). Freya is a PhD student in Psychology at the University of Birmingham, UK. Her work focuses on the linguistic processing of signed languages, especially in hearing learners of British Sign Language. Freya has been using R since 2017 for data analysis, dataviz, her personal website & now presentations! She also teaches introductory R to colleagues & fellow postgraduates.
Twitter: https://twitter.com/freya_watkins_
Website: https://freyawatkins.github.io/

WORKSHOP OVERVIEW
Sick of having twenty versions of the same file? Canâ€™t remember why you changed that line of code? Was it 6 weeks or 2 years ago? Did I add that bit or was it my colleague? In this introductory workshop, weâ€™ll learn about using version control via Git and GitHub, two powerful tools for keeping track of file changes and facilitating collaborative coding. Weâ€™ll also learn how to integrate version control into our RStudio workflow to keep our R code organised! There will be some basic interactive exercises to practice using Git & GitHub (creating a repository; cloning a repository; collaborating using forks). If youâ€™d like to follow along with the exercises, please make sure to do the below set-up/prep in advance. **This workshop will have British Sign Language-English interpretation.**

PREPARATION AND RESOURCES

1. (Install/)Update R and RStudio to the newest versions available to you.
2. If you donâ€™t already have one, create a free GitHub account at https://github.com

* Register with an academic email if you have one (more perks)
* Think carefully about your username: avoid spaces & uncommon characters; a shorter username is better than longer; usually your real name (or related to it) is best

3. Download GitHub Desktop from https://desktop.github.com
4. Install Git

* It is possible/likely you already have it
* There are thorough instructions for explaining how to check and what to do if you don't have it at: https://happygitwithr.com/install-git.html

If you have issues getting set up, or any access requirements, feel free to email Freya and she'll do her best to help:
f [dot] watkins [at] pgr [dot] bham [dot] ac [dot] uk

ONLINE PROGRAMME
The event will be held online and will start at 17:00 (GMT).
Please join us via this Zoom link:
https://us06web.zoom.us/j/82914984039?pwd=RTNVOWFES3ZCb3Qxb0RsaHovYVhXdz09

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: Using shiny to teach real world concepts like virus spread
description:
*What are we going to learn?

In this talk we'll be discussing the Shiny backend for a game that shows how virus spread occurs. Through gameplay one can easily explore complex ideas, like the interactive roles of quarantining and testing. No Shiny will be assumed, so the talk will be accessible to all levels and should be fun. We'll talk about the basics of coding reactive variables and how this relates to coding rules for a game.

*Who is going to present?

Kate Saunders is a lecturer in the School of Mathematical Sciences whose research interests are in statistical climatology. Her primary focus is on modelling climate extremes; and understanding how the probability of extreme events might be influenced by climate change. She also has a keen interest in data visualisation and R programming. An interest which helps her succeed in her research.

* When are we meeting?

***********The presentation will start at 5:00 pm (AEST)********************

The presentation will run for 45 minutes with 15 minutes for questions/mingling.

* Where are we meeting?
This talk will be held via Zoom

We look forward to seeing you there!

title: R-Ladies #21: Tidy Tuesday
description:
Join us for a new session on the 15th of March, 7:30PM EET ! We continue our meetups with #goodRvibes and a new dataset ready to be discovered.

#TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. An emphasis is placed on understanding how to summarize and arrange data to make meaningful charts with ggplot2, tidyr, dplyr, and other tools in the tidyverse ecosystem.
This meetup will be hands-on: after a brief introduction of #TidyTuesday and the weekly dataset, everyone will have a chance to explore the data and then share their work. Whether you want to practice exploratory visualization, apply a new analytical technique, try out a new plot theme or just learn tidyverse things from others, #TidyTuesday is for you.

To get a sense for #TidyTuesday ahead of time, check out the hashtag on Twitter, explore past datasets or check out David Robinson's screencasts below:
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeiiqmVK07qhY-wvg3IZiZQ
Registration is free, but mandatory via meetup. We shall meet on zoom, and the link will be updated on the day of the event ( PIN for entrance should be sent by email \~2hours before meeting start).
**CODE OF CONDUCT** : https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/
Please read our Code of Conduct before your first participation.

title: Creating Dynamic Reports from your Shiny App
description:
Workshop description:

So, you've created your wonderful, interactive Shiny app. But now you'd like to provide your users with a custom report that they can download. In this workshop, we'll start with a basic ready-made Shiny app (no need to build/bring your own!) and go over several packages that you can use to create dynamic reports with reactive Shiny elements.

About the speaker:

Sonja Winter (she/her) is a postdoctoral fellow at the Missouri Prevention Science Institute (MPSI) at the University of Missouri. She has worked on multiple Shiny apps that are used as educational and research tools. Prior to joining the MPSI, Sonja completed her Ph.D. in Quantitative Psychology at the University of California, Merced. Her research focuses on using Bayesian methods to resolve data analysis challenges in psychology and education.

Link will be provided closer to the event.

title: Using R as an Epidemiologist: Assessment of real-world data -w R-Ladies Gaborone
description:
We are so excited to collaborate with R-Ladies Gaborone to co-host the next event which will discuss how epidemiologists can use R in industry and academia.

Our speaker Brianna Lindsay will focus on how she approaches a dataset, and what important lessons learned about â€˜dirtyâ€™ real-world data and the basics of data exploration using R and R Studio.

WHO is this for?

- If you never worked with R and want to understand how it is used?
- If you love R and want to understand more about how it can be applied to real-world data.
- If you are an epidemiologist and want to start using R in your research
- Both beginners and experienced R users are welcome to join!

AGENDA
- 7:30â€“7:40 pm Who we are | Announcement about useR Conference 2022
- 7:35â€“8:25 pm Using R as an Epidemiologist
- 8:25â€“8:30 pm Any Qs?

What is Epidemiology?

Epidemiology is the study of the distribution and determinants of health-related states of events in specified populations..., (FrÃ©rot et al., Changing Definitions of epidemiology, 2017).

Brianna Lindsay, MPH, PhD, is an infectious disease epidemiologist based full-time in Zambia. She serves as primary epidemiologic personnel for the CDC/PEPFAR-funded CIRKUITS HIV treatment and prevention service delivery programs, supporting data collection, database design, and analysis. She also assists globally through programs in the affiliated Center for International Health, Education, and Biosecurity (Ciheb) at the University of Maryland Baltimore, supporting eight countries across sub-Saharan Africa. Dr. Lindsay applies quantitative data analysis to inform epidemiological investigations and practical research in infectious disease prevention and treatment in real-world settings. She has published extensively in burden of disease estimation using various study designs has expertise in quantitative methods as well as analysis of high-throughput and advanced molecular detection techniques. She has planned and organized a number of global health data workshops in Africa, Asia and the U.S.

More about her: https://twitter.com/brlindsay88

We look forward to welcoming you!

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to contact us :

#LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/r-ladies-saudi-arabia-dammam/
#Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-dammam/
#Twitter: https://twitter.com/RLadiesDammam

title: R tutorial series: Getting around GitHub
description:
Getting around GitHub can often be complicated to new users. Here we'll move into our R-Ladies Gainesville Tutorial Series with an introductory GitHub tutorial!

Michelle Slawinski ([https://github.com/slawinsm](https://github.com/slawinsm)) is going to guide us through how to use GitHub for version control and collaboration.

To participate, please complete the following before the event:
(1) create a GitHub account: [https://github.com/](https://github.com/)
(2) download and install Git: [https://github.com/git-guides/install-git](https://github.com/git-guides/install-git), more details [here](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-Installing-Git)
(3) download and install GitHub Desktop: [https://desktop.github.com/](https://desktop.github.com/), more details [here](https://docs.github.com/en/desktop/installing-and-configuring-github-desktop/overview/getting-started-with-github-desktop)
Note: We will be available to help you at 11:45AM - EST. If you run into any issues with the steps above, just join the Zoom call early :)

R-Ladies Gainesville welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling.

Please RSVP to access the Zoom link before the event.

Please note:
In line with R-Ladiesâ€™ Mission Statement to encourage participation in the R community by underrepresented genders/identities ([https://rladies.org/about-us/](https://rladies.org/about-us/)), our events are designed for those individuals (including, but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender). If you have any questions, please contact the event organizers.

title: Box package
description:
Martha Eichlersmith will introduce us to the box package. The box package allows the user to create specific modules within their code. It's kind of like making mini-packages. The main perks of using box are 1. modular code without creating a full package and 2. limiting/organizing the name space.

Slides: [mareichler.github.io/rladies_box_intro](https://MarEichler.github.io/rladies_box_intro/)
Github Repo: [github.com/MarEichler/rladies_box_intro](https://github.com/MarEichler/rladies_box_intro)

title: Plotting spatial data in R: Put R-Ladies Freiburg on the map!
description:
Have you ever been in awe when you saw beautiful maps created on Tidy Tuesdays and wished that you could create such maps? If so, this workshop is for you. We will use different Tidy Tuesday datasets including spatial information and recreate maps that you may have seen on social media. These include scatter maps, bubble maps and choropleth maps. To ease the start into the topic of creating maps with R, we will use {ggplot2}, a package most of you will be familiar with.
You will have the chance to practice your skills in several exercises. One of these will be a map in which you can provide your geolocation and appear as a dot on a world map thatâ€™ll show how global R-Ladies Freiburg has become.
The workshop will be given by our guest speaker Beke Hansen. Beke is a sociolinguist working at the University of Kiel and a long-time fan and member of R-Ladies Freiburg.

Note: We will not be recording this workshop, so be sure to attend on the day of the event if you are interested! As always, youâ€™ll also be able to find the materials in our Github repository:
https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_freiburg/tree/master/2022-03-10-Spatial_data_ggplot

title: Pick Your Package: Data Visualization in R
description:
When I hear "gg", I admit I don't think "ggplot" I think Gossip Girl.

But the truth is, "ggplot" is only one of the many packages available in R for data visualization.

At this event, the first R-Ladies NOLA event of 2022, we'll be vetting some of these packages and identifying which types of projects for which they work best.

Grab a drink, your notepad, your RStudio console and your powers of discernment and show up for a wonderful evening of learning, networking and random fun.

Any questions?

Email me, your R-Ladies NOLA organizer, at dikayo@dikayodata.com.

Cheers,
Danielle

title: Matrices, listas y dataframes en R

title: RLadies-Boulder #24: rtweet Tutorial!
description:
**SPEAKER:** This online event will be lead by Zane Dax ([https://twitter.com/StarTrek_Lt](https://twitter.com/StarTrek_Lt))! Zane has a BHsci in Public Health, started programming in Python but turned avid R user, and is very active on Twitter. She/They make R hexagon logos for R packages and streams on Twitch for data analysis and data visualizations.
**TOPIC OVERVIEW:** Twitter is a powerful tool and is part of a plethora of social media platforms. Twitter is widely used in the world for data science and research, as well as communication of various data science topics. Being a user is fine, but each tweet captures a lot of data that the user is unaware of - to unlock this hidden information one usually needs to have a Twitter API key to grab all the meta data on every tweet and Twitter user. In this special event, Zane will explain and walk through the rtweet package documentation ([https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rtweet/rtweet.pdf](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rtweet/rtweet.pdf)). She/They will provide explained and ready to go examples with the data ready for your own data analysis, such as text analysis from word counts from tweets collected. This is the only Twitter API tutorial that you get to fully enjoy and learn from without any worry about being granted a API key for your data analysis!PREPARATION AND
**RESOURCES:** There is nothing to prepare in advance. The tutorial resources are available on GitHub: [https://github.com/PythonCoderUnicorn/rtweet-tutorial](https://github.com/PythonCoderUnicorn/rtweet-tutorial)

title: How to do analysis for others without going crazy: My mistakes in consulting
description:
Hi everyone!

This month we are excited to host Dr. Taya Collyer, who will be giving a seminar on consulting and collaborating: How to do analysis without going crazy: My mistakes in consulting & collaborating

There is plenty of advice for 'statistical consultants' about how to improve practice and engament with clients. But not all of us are 'consultants', and there are a broad range of challenges (and power dynamics) which can accompany being the analysis person on a collaborative project. In this talk Taya will summarise the key lessons she has taken from nearly a decade of doing analysis for others, highlighting practical ways to make life easy for yourself and to maximise the benefit to your own career trajectory.

Dr. Taya Collyer is a biostatistician and public health researcher. Taya holds degrees in Economics, Biomedical science and Biostatistics, and a PhD from the university of Edinburgh, Scotland. Taya's statistical training centred around the design, conduct and analysis of very large Randomised Controlled Trials, and she began her career at the ASPREE Trial, one of Australia's largest ever RCTs of community-dwelling participants.

Taya is currently based at Monash University's Peninsula Clinical School, providing statistical support to the hospital-based academic unit, to clinicians within the health service, and to the federally-funded National Centre for Healthy Ageing, located on site. Taya most enjoys sharing joy in statistics with new audiences, and helping clinicians and researchers to get the most from their precious datasets.

This will be an online event. Please connect to the zoom session at 5:30pm on March 7th.

We look forward to seeing everyone at the event!

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: Free 2-Day Scientific Computing with â€œRâ€ Workshop 3/3-4
description:
The Institute for Data Science & Computing (IDSC) in collaboration with Software Carpentry bring a free 2 days R workshop.

S[oftware Carpentry](https://software-carpentry.org/) aims to help researchers get their work done in less time and with less pain by teaching them basic research computing skills. This hands-on workshop will cover basic concepts and tools, including program design, version control, data management, and task automation. Participants will be encouraged to help one another and to apply what they have learned to their own research problems.

**Thursday \+ Friday 3/3\-4/22 \| 9:00 AM â€“ 4:30 PM Course Hours\, Both Days**
**Registration Now Closed \| [Syllabus](https://gbianchi4.github.io/2022-03-03_UM_Scientific_Computing_R/) \| [Pre-workshop Survey](https://carpentries.typeform.com/to/wi32rS?slug=2022-03-03_UM_Scientific_Computing_R)**

**Who** This workshop is free and open to UM Faculty, Staff, and Students. The course is aimed at graduate students and other researchers.
You donâ€™t need to have any previous knowledge of the tools that will be presented at the workshop.

**Where** This training will take place online and in-person at the University of Miami Medical Campus, Don Soffer CRC Building, 1120 NW 14th Street, 7th Floor, CTSI Research Training Center (Room), Miami FL 33136. title: AI Ethics Workshop with Laura Summers
description:
Hi everyone,

For our next event we are very excited to host a joint event between R-Ladies Melbourne and Women in Machine Learning & Data Science (WiMLDS) Melbourne (https://www.meetup.com/Melbourne-Women-in-Machine-Learning-and-Data-Science/).

The event will feature the fabulous Laura Summers (she/her), a local expert in AI ethics. Laura is a multi-disciplinary designer researching technology ethics and building tools to promote fair machine learning.
She's the founder of debias.ai, the human behind Ethics Litmus Tests, fairXiv, and the Melbourne Fair ML reading group. Laura is passionate about feminism, digital rights and designing for privacy. She speaks, writes and runs workshops at the intersection of design and technology. You can follow Laura and her work on Twitter at @summerscope or via her website.

Talk abstract

Laura will kick us off with a quick survey of the state of the field, including jobs to do, thinking tools, tech tools, and ethical frameworks. We'll spend most of our time with a hands-on activity, testing and formalising our ethical intuitions and doing practical risk assessments. All levels of data literacy and machine learning knowledge are welcome, especially as (spoiler alert) most of the problems we create with automation and models are amplifying existing social inequality, rather than creating a new class of problem.

This will be an online event, held at the usual time 5.30-7pm. The zoom link will be available upon confirmation of attendance.

We look forward to seeing everyone at the event!

R-Ladies Melbourne & WiMLDS

title: Looking back @ my R journey : Tips and Tricks
description:
About the instructor:
Rahul Venugopal is a fourth-year Ph.D. scholar at the Centre for Consciousness Studies, NIMHANS, Bengaluru, India. His research revolves around understanding: how we experience the world as it is, how to improve intelligence/memory, and similar questions. He relies on many statistical & signal processing tools to make sense out of the brain. He has worked in multiple research projects involving topics like brain-computer interface, meditation, sleep, cognition, well-being, etc.

Abstract:
I am a consciousness researcher exploring various puzzles involving human minds, intelligence, and consciousness. This is an experiential talk looking back at my journey through the R verse. For my Ph.D. research work I had to model some complicated functions which were not available in conventional GUI based and one of my seniors in the lab suggested R. There it began. This talk is a reflection on challenges I faced in the process of learning R, all the things I wish I knew at multiple time points in the journey and type of mentors, I wish I dodged.

title: Workshop: An Introduction to Working with Geospatial Data in R
description:
For our February Meetup, we welcome R-Ladies NYC board member Ayanthi Gunawardana, who will teaching a workshop titled "An Introduction to Working with Geospatial Data in R." She will show participants how to import, process, and map geospatial data in R. Ayanthi will also introduce some basic geospatial concepts, different file formats, and best practices in creating maps. She will primarily be working with the sf package for processing the geospatial data, and ggplot2 for plotting the data.

RSVP for this workshop is via Google Form: https://forms.gle/a3fDSWuzLcxJuEEi9

Course materials will be available on Ayanthi's GitHub the day before the workshop: [https://github.com/argunaw/r-ladies-mapping-tutorial](https://github.com/argunaw/r-ladies-mapping-tutorial)

Agenda (tentative):
I. Basic geospatial concepts and files
\- Projections and coordinate systems
\- File formats for storing geospatial data
\- Common data sources for geospatial data
II. Downloading and Importing geospatial data in to R
\- Data processing for different file types
III. Presenting the Data
\- Accurately presenting geospatial data
\- Creating static maps for presentations \(ggplot2\)
\- Creating dynamic maps for exploratory purposes \(tmap\)

Instructor Biography:
Ayanthi has worked at the intersection of data and transportation for 6 years and has an academic background in city planning. She has been working with geospatial data for several years and has spent the past few years translating traditional geospatial practices to R.

***

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: Intro to Shiny: Interactive Dashboards for Beginners!
description:
Interactive, online dashboards for your plots and models is easy with the R package Shiny! No need to learn HTML, CSS, or any web-based programming language -- you can make a dashboard to host online entirely through R and R-Studio.

In this workshop, we'll explore the basics of your first Shiny app, drawing from the book Mastering Shiny by Hadley Wickham. We'll look at the essential components of any Shiny app and start to play with interactivity, so the users of your dashboard can change input values.

This will be the first of a couple workshops in which we will have the chance to refine our Shiny skills!

title: When to stop using Excel and start using R
description:
Details
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about When to stop using Excel and start using R.

Date/Time: Wednesday, February, 23rd 2022 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

â–¶ï¸ Invited trainer: Nathan Stephens

â–¶ï¸ About Nathan Stephens:
Nathan is a Senior Manager for Developer Relations at NVIDIA. His background is in analytic solutions and consulting.
He has experience building data science teams, architecting analytic
infrastructure, and delivering innovative data products. He is a longtime advocate foroperationalizing data science using open-source software. He is a longtime user of R.
Linkedin : https://www.linkedin.com/in/nwstephens/

â–¶ï¸ About the talk:
Spreadsheets are incredibly useful, especially when your data are small. But what happens when your data become too large and too complex for Excel? When that happens, your workbook can be difficult to maintain, and the integrity of your data may be compromised. In this
webinar, we will demonstrate the benefits of using the R programming language when Excel gets overloaded.
What do we mean by â€œtoo largeâ€?
â— Too many rows - 1,048,576
â— Too many columns - 16,384
â— Too many workbooks - 255
What do we mean by "too complexâ€?
â— Too many data sources
â— Too many complex functions
â— Too much VBA code and user interactivity

Make sure to join us!
In order to attend the event, please fill out this form ğŸ‘‰
https://tinyurl.com/2p9svznw

We will send you the zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

We look forward to welcoming you!

title: Dimensionality Reduction Tutorial: PCA & UMAP
description:
Speaker Bio - Anabel Ruggiero (she/her)
Anabel is a computational engineer whose interests lie in the intersection of applied mathematics and software engineering. She received her doctorate in Chemical Engineering at Oklahoma State University, where she conducted research in the field of computational biosystems. Her current research work is NNDescent.cpp, a cache efficient and distributable reimplementation of PyNNDescent. In December 2021, she joined Stellar Science as a computational engineer.

Workshop details
This workshop is a tutorial on dimensionality reduction. Dimensionality reduction is a useful technique for data visualization and as an initial layer of a model. This makes it a powerful tool in a data scientist's arsenal. Anabel will go over the basics of the math and algorithms behind PCA, tSNE, and UMAP. Most of the time will be devoted to an R example implementing these algorithms.

We recommend that participants have some familiarity with the basics of linear algebra and statistics, and an understanding of matrices, linear transformations, and statistical distributions.

Date and time: Feb 23, 2022 at 6:00pm
Zoom link: RSVP to view the link (password follows `?pwd=` in the link)
If you have trouble getting into the meeting, please message Jasmine

See you there!

Yuka, Jasmine and Lisa

**********************IMPORTANT************************

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready

2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

3. Who is allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

title: Getting started with reproducibility and R markdown
description: We will go over some basics of reproducibility and how to use R markdown to combine text, code, and output! Come excited and prepared to do a bit of live editing of R markdown code!

title: Teach Me How to Google
description:
Workshop description:

Googling for code help is something that all data scientists (at all career stages) do. But figuring out how to get the information you need back can be incredibly challenging, particularly for new coders. In this talk, weâ€™ll discuss strategies for refining your queries to increase your chances of finding informative solutions.
https://samanthacsik.github.io/teach-me-how-to-google/slides/RLadiesSTL-2022-02-22.html#1

About the speaker:

Sam Csik (pronounced â€œchickâ€) is the Data Training Coordinator at the National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis (NCEAS) located at UC Santa Barbara, where she is working to develop and teach data science training curricula for the Masterâ€™s of Environmental Data Science (MEDS) program and other data science initiatives across NCEAS and UCSB. She is also co-organizer of R-Ladies Santa Barbara, a local data science group which works to promote diversity in the R community. In her spare time, youâ€™ll typically find her hiking with her pup or cooking family dinners with friends.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Data Privacy Preserving Applications with R (Virtual)
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is excited to host a meetup on Tuesday February 22, 2022 from 3-4:30pm (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have an informative presentation from Claire McKay Bowen (@ClaireMKBowen, https://clairemckaybowen.com), Principal Research Associate at the Urban Institute. She will be giving an introduction to data privacy preserving applications in R. Materials for the presentation can be found at https://github.com/ClaireMcKayBowen/r-ladies-baltimore-privacy-talk

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R and want to learn how to use data privacy preserving applications
- If you know R, but want to expand your knowledge about maintaining data privacy and confidentiality in your work

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA
3:00â€“3:15pm Who we are | Announcements | What's next
3:15â€“4 pm Presentation: Data Privacy Preserving Applications in R
4â€“4:30pm Networking -- Any more Qs?

Details on the location:
The Zoom information will be sent to those who RSVP the week before the event.

FAQ:
Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:
- If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

Finally, for more information:

twitter: @RLadiesBmore
facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RLadiesBmore/
meetup: https://www.meetup.com/rladies-baltimore/

title: Empowering Women in Data (Science)
description:
R-Ladies Cologne is kicking off with a roundtable on "Empowering Women in Data (Science)" on February 21, 2022, at 7 pm CET. We are excited to have four fantastic speakers from across the globe working in different fields to share their experiences, tips, tricks, and challenges with us! ğŸš€

Our four amazing panelists are:

âœ¨ Alison Hill (Ph.D., Senior Data Scientist, AI Strategy & Innovation @IBM)

âœ¨ Ana Carolina Leote (PhD Candidate @ Cologne Graduate School of Ageing Research)

âœ¨ AngÃ©lica Becerra (Data Scientist @ cynkra GmbH)

âœ¨ Nina Hauser (Head of Data Literacy @ CorrelAid e.V.)

To learn more about our speakers before the event, have a look at their short introductions.

**Alison Hill, Ph.D., Senior Data Scientist, AI Strategy & Innovation @IBM**

I am a data scientist, behavioral scientist, and award-winning educator. I work on creating online experiences to bring machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI) problems and solutions to life. My goal is to make AI more approachable, understandable, and empowering. For 3 years, I worked at RStudio, where most recently I was the Product Manager for Data Science Communication. I am also a co-developer of the `palmerpenguins`, `distill`, and `blogdown` R packages, as well an author and international keynote speaker.

**Ana Carolina Leote, PhD Candidate @ Cologne Graduate School of Ageing Research**

Carolina moved from Lisbon to Cologne in order to pursue her PhD in Bioinformatics. She uses R and data science to make sense of high throughput biological data and learn about human health and ageing.

**AngÃ©lica Becerra, Data Scientist @ cynkra GmbH**

Angelica is a statistician and data scientist with experience in consulting governmental offices on developing large-scale survey studies and statistical analysis. Angelica has an M.Sc. in Social and Economic Data Analysis from the University of Konstanz, Germany. After her studies, she has developed data analysis projects using R and Python with a strong focus on data cleansing, data visualization, web scraping, and automated reports.

**Nina Hauser, Head of Data Literacy @ CorrelAid e.V.**

Nina works as Head of Data Literacy at CorrelAid e.V. and helps social organizations keep track of the buzzword jungle around Data Science, Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning. As a data scientist (trained at Imperial College London) and ex-Deloitte, she knows the consulting jargon that makes Data Science omnipresent - but also exclusive. Her more pragmatic view today is based on her experience working for the World Food Programme and as an impact measurement consultant.

To join the event, sign up on Meetup - we will share the Zoom link with the registered participants beforehand.

We are very much looking forward to welcoming you all to our kick-off meeting! â˜ºï¸

title: Job hunting for Data Analysts: Why it's hard and what one can do about it
description:
Happy new year 2022, members!

We welcome you to our first meetup of the year:

Topic: Job hunting for Data Analysts: Why it's hard and what one can do about it

Date: February 19th, 2022 11 AM - 1 PM (GMT+3)

Trainer: Oscar Baruffa

Biography: Oscar Baruffa is a Data Specialist helping non-profits achieve the United Nations Sustainable Development goals and is currently working in the international development sector directing the development of a full data and analytics pipeline. Previous roles have seen him modeling energy consumption of buildings, auditing energy use and carbon emission metrics, and closely following macro and micro-economic trends in plastic recycling value chains. His 15-year career has seen him on both sides of the hiring table many times and has valuable insights to share.

â¡ï¸ The presentation will aim to demystify the hiring process and give concrete examples of how to improve one's chances.

Oscar will explain why it is that applying to hundreds of jobs can still result in getting no interviews or even responses. Heâ€™ll help to alleviate the "sense of failure" from participants. Heâ€™ll then go on to the single biggest improvement he thinks people can make, and that's to their CV and cover letter. Heâ€™s seen so many poor ones that can be improved in the same way. Heâ€™ll also touch on a strategy he uses when job hunting to conserve his energy and emotional state!

We will share the zoom link with the registered participants.

All are welcome!

For any comments & questions, contact us on;

Email address: nairobi@rladies.org

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/r-ladies-nairobi-2572841b3/

Twitter: @RLadiesNairobi

title: Join our team! R-Ladies NYC Board Information Session
description:
If getting more involved with your local R-Ladies New York chapter was on your list of 2022 resolutions, hereâ€™s your chance! We are looking for new members to join us as event organizers on the R-Ladies NYC Board.

This information session will be a meet and greet with current board members: weâ€™ll introduce ourselves, explain responsibilities and the expected time commitment of a board member, and highlight initiatives weâ€™d like to pursue in 2022. The application for new board members is now available (due Sunday, March 6th): https://forms.gle/BMv1GKW3pfxZDeFK9

We are happy to take questions and suggestions for future meetups from our community, so please feel free to attend with feedback even if you may not be interested in joining the board as an organizer.

If you are interested in joining the board but are unable to attend this meeting, please connect with us via Slack or email us at nyc@rladies.org with your questions, thoughts, and comments. Weâ€™ll be happy to follow up with more information!

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event. We will request your email address upon registration to ensure you receive the Zoom passcode.

---

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: Three reasons to use tidymodels
description:
Modeling and machine learning in R involve a bewildering array of heterogeneous packages, and establishing good statistical practice is challenging in any language. The tidymodels collection of packages offers a consistent, flexible framework for your modeling and machine learning work to address these problems. In this talk, speaker Julia Silge will focus on three specific reasons to consider using tidymodels. She will start with model characteristics themselves, move to the wise management of your data budget, and finish with feature engineering.

Check out tidymodels here: https://www.tidymodels.org/

*About the speaker*
Julia Silge is a data scientist and software engineer at RStudio PBC where she works on open-source modeling tools. She is an author, an international keynote speaker, and a real-world practitioner focusing on data analysis and machine learning. Julia loves text analysis, making beautiful charts, and communicating about technical topics with diverse audiences.

Website: https://juliasilge.com/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/juliasilge

*Registration*
Fill out this Google Form to register, and you'll receive the Zoom link by email: https://forms.gle/GiuFfHmGv8fy2Eph9

title: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group (on a Wednesday)
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

This will be the **second** part of a multipart TidyTuesday event where we will be looking at a local (!) urban heat mapping dataset brought to us by collaborators at the [Museum of Life and Science](https://www.lifeandscience.org/) and the [State Climate Office of NC](https://climate.ncsu.edu/). These data were collected using [PocketLab temperature sensors](https://www.thepocketlab.com/store/pocketlab-weather?hsLang=en) as folks walked around Durham and Raleigh this past summer. You can read hear more about this project in this WUNC feature [here](https://www.wunc.org/race-demographics/2021-08-11/urban-heat-mapping-project-durham-race-policies-climate-google).

Agenda (all times in ET):
6:00 - 6:15 pm Meet & Greet
6:15 - 7:10 pm #tidytuesday
7:10 - 7:30 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out [this blog post](https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt) and [the main repository page](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: 2022 Datathon Kickoff
description:
Do you want to practice your data skills while helping a good cause? Join R-Ladies Philly and DataPhilly for a 6-week datathon focused on exploring data for ElderNet, a local non-profit organization whose mission is to help elderly and disabled citizens maintain their independence at home. We will help them explore, stratify, and visualize their support services to ultimately tell a data story of ElderNet's impact in the Lower Merion and Narbeth region. We will be working on a deidentified subset of these data in order to:

* better understand the needs of our elderly and disabled population through data
* hone our data science skills
* learn and practice R, Python, and/or other languages you decide to use (there will be ways to contribute for people of all levels of experience with coding)
* get our hands dirty and our heads spinning with rich and messy real-world data
* work together, network, and make (new) friends in the data world!
* have fun nerding out together over data :)

The repository for the datathon can be found here: https://github.com/rladiesPHL/2022_datathon

ElderNet: https://eldernetonline.org/about/

See you there!

title: RMarkdown: Create insightful reports in R
description:
Hello to you all. This month we are honored to have Thiyanga Talagala, a Senior Lecturer and Data Scientist as our special guest speaker.
She would be taking us through how to tell data stories with R Markdown. R Markdown gives us the power to turn our analyses into high-quality documents, reports, presentations, and dashboards.
We look forward to seeing you. Thank you

title: Detalle EstadÃ­stico de San ValentÃ­n
description:
Los tiempos han cambiado y la manera en la que nos relacionamos con nuestros seres queridos tambiÃ©n; mientras hay personas que continÃºan disfrutando de una salida o una llamada por telÃ©fono, otros prefieren la comunicaciÃ³n por redes sociales, compartir un emoji o un meme puede significar mucho en las interacciones que tenemos con nuestros seres queridos... Â¿Te has puesto a pensar cuÃ¡nto has texteado con tu mejor amix en la Ãºltima semana? o Â¿CuÃ¡ndo es mÃ¡s comÃºn que le escribas a tu mamÃ¡ o a tu papÃ¡?
Bueno, en este taller podrÃ¡s hacer un anÃ¡lisis de frecuecia y texto sobre tus mensajes de Whatsapp en R: un "detalle" diferente para este DÃ­a del Amor y la Amistad.

El taller serÃ¡ vÃ­a Zoom y previo a este necesitarÃ¡s realizar los siguientes pasos:

PASO 1. Se requiere que instales previamente estas librerÃ­as:

library(rwhatsapp)
library(lubridate)
library(tidyverse)
library(tidytext)
library(kableExtra)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(knitr)

PASO 2. Exportar el historial del Chat en Whatsapp con tu ser querido, es muy sencillo:

Desde tu WhatsApp en cualquier conversaciÃ³n abierta, da clic en el menÃº de los tres puntos de la parte arriba derecha en Opciones/MÃ¡s/Exportar chat. e inmediato a esto podrÃ¡s enviarte el historial completo como archivo de texto con extensiÃ³n â€œ.txtâ€ a un correo. Preferentemente utiliza la opciÃ³n sin multimedia, ya que la descarga estÃ¡ restringuida hasta cierta cantidad de informaciÃ³n, por lo que, dependediendo de cÃ³mo sea tu interacciÃ³n con la persona podrÃ­as ver mensajes de aÃ±os o apenas de unos meses atrÃ¡s.
Nota: Se debe tener en consideraciÃ³n que para que las grÃ¡ficas de frecuencia sean mÃ¡s precisas, las plÃ¡ticas en Whatsapp deberÃ­an estar en horario de 24hrs, si tu celular registra la hora con AM y PM, no se verÃ¡ como en el taller.

** La liga de conexiÃ³n se compartirÃ¡ el dÃ­a de la sesiÃ³n, por este mismo medio.

title: Best of 2021: Data Visualization with ggplot2
description:
2021 was a great year for R-Ladies Freiburg! As the new year begins, let's review our favorite tips and tricks from last year's workshops.

In this workshops, we'll go through the tips and tricks that leveled up our plotting skills last year, from adding colors to fonts to annotations and more. We'll go over which additional packages and commands can help you make your plots just the way you imagined them!

title: Automate your CV using R Markdown: Easy as 1, 2, knit
description:
Hi Everyone!

We are very excited to announce R Ladies Melbourne's first event of 2022! This event will be presented by Dr. Shazia Ruybal-PesÃ¡ntez, R Ladies Melbourne President and Postdoctoral Research Scientist at WEHI and Burnet Institute.

Updating your CV can be a tedious, but very necessary task! Most often this process involves creating and updating a user-created template in e.g. a Word document and fiddling with formatting for longer than one would like to admit, especially when it is time to update the content. With R Markdown, you can quickly turn your CV into a beautiful, automated document that is easy to produce, maintain and update to suit your specific needs. With this automated approach, the only thing you really have to worry about and devote your time to is writing the content.

In this talk, Shazia will take you through the R packages â€œdatadrivencvâ€, â€œpagedownâ€ and â€œvitaeâ€ that can be used with R Markdown to create and automate your CV. The aim is to guide you through how to save your data in a readable format for these packages, how to set up your R Markdown document, and how to render the output in different formats, all so that you can automate your pipeline to quickly and easily update your CV! This talk should give you sufficient information and materials that you can customize and either follow along during the talk or create your CV on your own after the talk.

This will be an online event. Please connect to the **lunchtime** zoom session at midday/12pm Melbourne time on Friday the 4th of February.

We look forward to seeing everyone at the event!

R-Ladies Melbourne

title: Accessible DataViz
description:
Data visualizations and presentations are often unintentionally designed in a way that makes them inaccessible to a few participants. Come learn how to make your data visualizations and presentations accessible to everyone!

Fill out this Google Form to register, and you'll receive the Zoom link by email: https://forms.gle/RnR2jfqbWqGH7qWXA

Our first speaker, *Keke Wu* (PhD student at Univ of Colorado, Boulder) will talk about her research, Understanding Data Accessibility for People with Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities (IDD), giving us concrete ideas about how to make better figures and reach the IDD community.

Keke is a filmmaker, a storyteller, a designer, a developer, and a researcher. She has degrees in Digital Media Technology and Japanese Language and Literature, a Master of Fine Arts in Film and Television Production, and is currently working on her PhD in Creative Technology & Design at the University of Colorado Boulder. Her research focuses on visualization and accessibility through the lens of multimedia design and storytelling.

Website: https://www.kekewu.me/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/kekewu728

Our second speaker, *Andrea Gomez Vargas* (one of the winners of the 'most accessible presentation' award at useR! 2021), will talk about how to make an accessible presentation in R, using packages such as RMarkdown.

Andrea studied sociology at the University of Buenos Aires and is currently a sociologist, teacher, and researcher with a focus on gender studies and human rights. She is also a co-organizer of R Ladies Buenos Aires and a part of LatinR.

Website: https://soyandrea.netlify.app/
Twitter: https://twitter.com/me_andre

title: Creating and sharing R tutorials
description:
Online R tutorials are some of the most effective ways to troubleshoot problems and learn new skills. While we may appreciate tutorials, it can be hard to prioritize making our own to share with the R community. In this meeting, we'll kick off the R-Ladies Gainesville Tutorial Series!

Do you have a solution to a tricky R problem? Is there an R package you've been wanting to learn? The Tutorial Series will provide a framework for formalizing your knowledge, sharing it with other R-Ladies, and getting feedback. We will provide an introduction to tutorials and discuss approaches to making your own.

To follow along, we recommend having R and RStudio installed on your computer, as well as the "rmarkdown" and "tidyverse" R packages.

R-Ladies Gainesville welcomes members of all R proficiency levels, whether you're a new or aspiring R user, or an experienced R programmer interested in mentoring, networking & expert upskilling.

Please RSVP to access the Zoom link before the event.

Please note:
In line with R-Ladiesâ€™ Mission Statement to encourage participation in the R community by underrepresented genders/identities (https://rladies.org/about-us/), our events are designed for those individuals (including, but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender). If you have any questions, please contact the event organizers.

title: Best of 2021: Data Wrangling with the tidyverse
description:
2021 was a great year for R-Ladies Freiburg! As the new year begins, let's review our favorite tips and tricks from last year's workshops.

In this first of two workshops, we'll go through the most life-changing data wrangling tips we learned last year. These commands make it easy to get your data in exactly the right format for graphs or statistical modeling and make your workflows more reproducible and less error-prone!

We'll end the hour-long workshop with a little data wrangling challenge for you to refresh your data wrangling skills. If you have less experience with data manipulation, don't hesitate to join, and if you're looking for a refresher, check out our past workshops on Youtube (https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLPwprT5wdzX7NVDl4oYQ7c2_6ox0_1fyr).

Image by Allison Horst (https://github.com/allisonhorst/stats-illustrations).

title: [HYBRID] #tidytuesday Work Group (on a Thursday)
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event hybrid (zoom and face-to-face), where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

[TBD description of the dataset]

Agenda (all times in ET):
5:00 - 5:15 pm Meet & Greet
5:15 - 6:15 pm #tidytuesday
6:15 - 6:30 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post (https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt) and the main repository page (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
This event is a hybrid event. For those joining virtually, we will send you a email with a Zoom link the day before the event to everyone who RSVP'ed.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

title: Time series analysis in R
description:
We are delighted to invite you to our next meetup. We will be organizing a new meetup about time series in R.

Date/Time: Wednesday, Junuary, 26th 2022 from 6 PM to 7 PM (GMT+1)
Place: Zoom

â–¶ï¸ Invited trainer: Veerle van Leemput

â–¶ï¸ About Veerle van Leemput :

Veerle van Leemput (https://www.linkedin.com/in/veerlevanleemput/) is an entrepreneur and Data Scientist who gets excited about data and programming. She is Managing Director and Head of Data Science at Analytic Health, a UK-based company that develops intelligent and accessible technology which gives organisations the tools they need to accelerate innovation in healthcare. She is an R developer with a Masterâ€™s Degree in Data Science and multiple years of experience in the pharmaceutical market. Besides programming in R and making R Shiny applications, she also develops multiple web applications for healthcare organisations using Vue.js and Node at Analytic Health.

â–¶ï¸ About the talk:

When you think about anything to do with machine learning, many people instantly think of Python. And thatâ€™s because there are great packages for Python like scikit-learn that make Python an excellent choice to make models and solve machine learning problems. But did you know that R offers many machine learning packages as well? During this meetup, Veerle will tell more about making demand forecasts specifically. She will go into detail about how theyâ€™re using R to do time series analysis and make demand forecasts for medicine supply at Analytic Health. If you want to learn more about the basics of doing a proper time series analysis, the Prophet algorithm developed by Facebook, and other relevant packages and tools to model your time series in R, make sure to join us!
In order to attend the event, please fill out this form ğŸ‘‰

We will send you the zoom link a few hours before the training session. Please check out your email later.

title: How to unlock Twitter's hidden meta data: An introduction to the rtweet package
description:
SPEAKER
This online event will be lead by Zane Dax (https://twitter.com/StarTrek_Lt)! Zane has a BHsci in Public Health, started programming in Python but turned avid R user, and is very active on Twitter. She/They make R hexagon logos for R packages and streams on Twitch for data analysis and data visualizations.

TOPIC OVERVIEW
Twitter is a powerful tool and is part of a plethora of social media platforms. Twitter is widely used in the world for data science and research, as well as communication of various data science topics. Being a user is fine, but each tweet captures a lot of data that the user is unaware of - to unlock this hidden information one usually needs to have a Twitter API key to grab all the meta data on every tweet and Twitter user. In this special event, Zane will explain and walk through the rtweet package documentation (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rtweet/rtweet.pdf). She/They will provide explained and ready to go examples with the data ready for your own data analysis, such as text analysis from word counts from tweets collected. This is the only Twitter API tutorial that you get to fully enjoy and learn from without any worry about being granted a API key for your data analysis!

PREPARATION AND RESOURCES
There is nothing to prepare in advance. The tutorial resources are available on GitHub: https://github.com/PythonCoderUnicorn/rtweet-tutorial

ONLINE PROGRAMME
The event will be held online and will start at 17:30 (GMT).
Please join us via this Zoom link:
https://us06web.zoom.us/j/87625213388?pwd=ZjBQMjNINHZsZVRVMHI1L2pMMnZRdz09

CODE OF CONDUCT
Please take a minute to read our code of conduct - we are committed to creating a safe and harassment-free environment:
https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

R-Ladies events are always free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as they follow the code of conduct. We are pro-actively inclusive of queer, trans, and all minority identities, with additional sensitivity to intersectional identities. Our priority is to provide a safe community space for anyone identifying as a minority gender who is interested in and/or working with R.

title: My Favourite Things (about R)
description:
Which packages do you include in the first chunk of every analysis? What about functions that make your R life easier every day?

There are a handful of data wrangling and visualisation packages/functions that end up every script I write. Come along and learn about my favourite R things and share yours too at this online event.

title: R-Ladies #19 Build a new habit in 2022: Tidy Tuesday
description:
Join us for a new session on the 25th of January, 7PM EET ! We continue our meetups with #goodRvibes and a challenge to engage in new habits.

Title: Build a new habit in 2022! Tidy Tuesday

#TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. An emphasis is placed on understanding how to summarize and arrange data to make meaningful charts with ggplot2, tidyr, dplyr, and other tools in the tidyverse ecosystem.

This meetup will be hands-on: after a brief introduction of #TidyTuesday and the weekly dataset, everyone will have a chance to explore the data and then share their work. Whether you want to practice exploratory visualization, apply a new analytical technique, try out a new plot theme or just learn tidyverse things from others, #TidyTuesday is for you.

To get a sense for #TidyTuesday ahead of time, check out the hashtag on Twitter, explore past datasets or check out David Robinson's screencasts below:

https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeiiqmVK07qhY-wvg3IZiZQ
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Registration is free, but mandatory via meetup. We shall meet on zoom, and the link will be updated on the day of the event ( PIN for entrance should be sent by email ~2hours before meeting start).
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
CODE OF CONDUCT : https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/
Please read our Code of Conduct before your first participation.

title: R packages for data cleaning
description:
*What are we going to learn?
About R packages used for data cleaning, such as naniar, janitor, datawizard, amelia and data.table

library(amelia)
library(naniar)
library(datawizard)
library(data.table)
library(janitor)

*Who is going to present?
Simisani Ndaba from https://twitter.com/RLadiesGaborone
Simisani has a history of working in the higher education industry having been working at the Department of Computer Science at the University of Botswana as a Teaching Assistant since 2016. She graduated with her Masters of Science in Computer Information Systems where her research work was based on Information Retrieval in Authorship Identification using authorsâ€™ writing styles PAN at CLEF. PAN is a series of scientific events and shared tasks on digital text forensics and stylometry. Prior to that, she worked as a Business Analyst at the Gauteng Department of Education working on data management and business intelligence in South Africa. She also holds a Bachelorâ€™s degree in Business Information Systems and is due to complete a Post Graduate Diploma in Education, a teacher/trainer qualification in October 2021. She is part of the Ladies in R Botswana based in the University of Botswana and is an assistant in Health Informatics Africa.

* When are we meeting?
The talk will start at 6:00 pm for approximately 45 mins, followed by 45 minutes Q&A and networking!

***********The presentation will start at 6:00 pm (AEST)********************

* Where are we meeting?
This talk will be held via Zoom

We look forward to seeing you there!

R-Ladies Brisbane

Photos, Films and all other media/recordings: Photographs and/or video/other media will be taken at events held by this community. By taking part in an R-Ladies Brisbane event you grant the community organisers full rights to use the images resulting from the photography/video filming/media, and any reproductions or adaptations of the images for publicity, fund-raising or other purposes to help achieve the communityâ€™s aims. This might include (but is not limited to), the right to use them in their printed and online publicity, social media, press releases and funding applications. If you do not wish to be recorded in these media please inform a community organiser.

Code of Conduct: R-Ladies Brisbane is dedicated to providing a welcoming and harassment-free event experience for everyone, regardless of gender, gender identity and expression, age, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, ethnicity, or religion (or lack thereof). We do not tolerate harassment of event participants in any form, for any event venue, including talks, workshops, parties, Twitter and other online media.

Community Policies: Please note, cis men are welcome to join our meetups when they come as a guest of a woman participant or they bring a woman with them. We highly encourage speakers and teachers at R-Ladies Brisbane events to be of minority genders.

Find us on Twitter @rladiesbrisbane and https://github.com/rladies/meetup-presentations_brisbane for more information, news, presentations and code!

title: R packages for data cleaning
description:
R-Ladies Brisbane hosts an event for R-Ladies Gaborone on the introduction to R packages for data cleaning, such as Naniar, Janitor, StringR and more with Simisani Ndaba as speaker .

Simisani Ndaba has a history of working in the higher education industry having been working at the Department of Computer Science at the University of Botswana as a Teaching Assistant since 2016. She graduated with her Masters of Science in Computer Information Systems where her research work was based on Information Retrieval in Authorship Identification using authorsâ€™ writing styles PAN at CLEF. PAN is a series of scientific events and shared tasks on digital text forensics and stylometry. Prior to that, she worked as a Business Analyst at the Gauteng Department of Education working on data management and business intelligence in South Africa. She also holds a Bachelorâ€™s degree in Business Information Systems and a Post Graduate Diploma in Education, a trainer qualification in October 2021. She is the founder and co-organiser of R-Ladies Gaborone is an assistant in Health Informatics Africa.
https://twitter.com/RLadiesGaborone

title: Git/Github workshop
description:
Speaker Bio - Shannon Lo (she/her)
Shannon is a data professional who has worked in various industries including telecom, retail, and public health. Her current work involves topic-specific analyses on the Canadian Coroner and Medical Examiner Database. When she's not geeking out about data, you can usually find her hiking, snowshoeing, or camping.

Workshop details
This workshop will equip you with the basics of the version control software git and how to collaborate with others on Github. Participants will be able to pull, commit and push by the end of this session as well as branch and fork repos. This workshop is recommended for anyone attending as it is an important piece in online coding collaborations.

If you want to follow along during the workshop please make sure you have installed Git on your computer and created an account with Github. Shannon also has provided step by step instructions previously here: https://shannonhlo.github.io/projects/git-github-workshop1/

Date and time: Jan 20, 2020 at 6:00pm
Webinar link: RSVP to view link
If you have trouble getting into the meeting, please message Jasmine

See you there!

Yuka, Jasmine and Lisa

**********************IMPORTANT************************

1. Have your computer and a steady internet connection ready

2. If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/.github/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

3. Who is allowed to attend the workshop?
Everyone is welcome to join us at our events and to be a part of our mission to empower gender minorities with the skills and knowledge to code in one of the top programming languages in data science, which is R.

To fulfill this mission we do ask participants to respect a focus on the encouragement and support for women and non-binary people during our events.

title: Reactor x PNW Tech Community Networking
description:
Join us at a networking event hosted by the Microsoft Reactor and partners - the PNW chapters of Seattle PyLadies, R-Ladies Seattle, and Data Circles. This is an opportunity to meet folks and hear from a few incredible community groups.

Register here or on the Reactor's Meetup page: https://www.meetup.com/Microsoft-Reactor-Redmond/events/282700053

Who is it aimed at?
If you are a part of the tech community or if you are interested in meeting people in the world of tech, this is an event you wonâ€™t want to miss.

Why should I attend?
If you miss connecting with your peers, join us to learn about fantastic community groups and meet industry professionals.

More about the groups we'll be joining!
PyLadies:
Seattle PyLadies is a Python programming group that welcomes members from all over the Puget Sound region. We started the Seattle chapter in 2012 and have grown to > 2000 members. PyLadies is an international mentorship group with a focus on helping more women become active participants and leaders in the Python open-source community. Our mission is to promote, educate and advance a diverse Python community through outreach, education, conferences, events and social gatherings.

Data Circles:
Data Circles started as Sea-WiDS (Seattle Women in Data Science). Data Circles exists to provide a place for women in data science to connect, build community, support each other and grow. Although we focus on empowerment of women, everybody is welcome to our events. We offer technical talks, workshops, networking opportunities, interview preparation sessions and more. Learn more about us at datacircles.org and, by joining the community you will enter our Slack space and connect to everyone in the community.

title: "R" Goals for 2022!
description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, January 18, 6:30-8:30 pm (Pacific)
6:30 - Welcome and Networking
7:00 - Announcements
7:10 - "R" Goals for Learning R in 2022
7:50 - "R" Goals for R-Ladies Irvine in 2022
8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

Join us Tuesday, January 18, for networking, followed by announcements and two Q&A sessions:

# "R" Goals for Learning R in 2022

A fun discussion about R-Ladies Irvine co-organizers' and attendees' goals for learning R in 2022. Some questions for the group include:

- What is one thing that you use in R that is indispensable?
- What is the most important/surprising thing you have learned about R in the last year/month/week?
- What is one thing you want to learn about R?
- What is the funniest or weirdest task related to data analysis/statistics you've learned to do recently?

# "R" Goals for R-Ladies Irvine in 2022

A presentation of the goals the co-organizers have for the group this year and a request for suggestions of what you would like to see and think we could improve this year.

title: Resolutions 2022!
description: For our January 2022 meetup we'll go over survey results and where we are hoping to go in 2022. Then, we will have some time to network via break out rooms while answering R Ladies and Philadelphia related trivia questions! Please join us for our networking and more social meetup to start the new year!

title: Package Development Workshop (Day 2) - Package Documentation
description:
We are thrilled to kick off our 2022 programming by welcoming Joyce Robbins to lead us through a two-day interactive package development workshop! This second hour-long module will guide participants through types of and tools for package documentation. It builds upon material from â€œPackage Development Day 1 - Your First Packageâ€ (see Meetup event https://www.meetup.com/rladies-newyork/events/283033216/), however participants can join this second session independently. Besides familiarity with R/RStudio and basic function writing, there are no prerequisites.

RSVP for this workshop is via Google Form: https://forms.gle/3rkuU8CZDMBrudfK8/.

Course materials are available here: https://github.com/jtr13/pkgdev/. Please note the â€œPre-workshop setupâ€ instructions for Windows and Mac.

Agenda for Day 2 (tentative):
Noon-1 pm: Lesson
- devtools::check(): checking a package
- Naming your package
- Licensing your package
- Adding dependencies
- Adding examples to documentation
- Creating vignettes
- Using git/GitHub
- Where next?
1-1:30 pm: Lab with Joyce and teaching assistants Erin Grand and Emily Dodwell

Instructor Biography:
Joyce Robbins, Ph.D., is Lecturer in Discipline in the Statistics Department at Columbia University, where she specializes in data visualization. She is a member of the R Forwards (R Foundation taskforce on women and other under-represented groups) teaching team, previously served as publications officer of the Statistical Graphics Section of the American Statistical Association Section, and is an active member of RLadies NYC.

---

Many thanks to Mine Ã‡etinkaya-Rundel and Emma Rand of the R Forwards Teaching Team for their creation of the package development workshop modules on which this session is based. For more information, see https://forwards.github.io/workshops/.

---

R-Ladies is dedicated to providing a harassment-free experience for everyone. We do not tolerate harassment of participants in any form. Please take a moment to review the R-Ladies Global code of conduct (particularly if this is your first time attending!): https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct

title: RLadies #22: Frequentist & Bayesian Random Effects Models in R: RStan Tutorial
description:
This month's guest speaker Amanda Koepke will present on random effects modeling in RStan:

A common problem in science, medicine, and other fields is the need to combine independent measurements (taken over multiple days, or at different labs, or using different measurement methods) into a consensus estimate in a way that recognizes explicitly the contributions that different sources of uncertainty (i.e., within-study uncertainties and between-study differences) make to the overall uncertainty. Many methods exist for this, and past studies have compared the performance of different estimation approaches, however little attention has been paid to Bayesian approaches. In this talk, I will briefly describe my work extending these estimator comparisons to Bayesian models and exploring which approaches are best for common data scenarios at NIST (https://www.nist.gov/). I will then give a short tutorial on how to implement this type of Bayesian analysis in R using RStan. The Hamiltonian Monte Carlo used in RStan provides a very efficient way to explore the posterior distribution and allows for the most natural definition of specialized probability distributions. However, it can be tricky to consistently obtain valid samples when trying to fit many simulated datasets with realistic simulation settings. I'll describe some of the issues I encountered and how to deal with some common RStan warnings.

title: Teach Me How to Google
description:
Workshop description:

Googling for code help is something that all data scientists (at all career stages) do. But figuring out how to get the information you need back can be incredibly challenging, particularly for new coders. In this talk, weâ€™ll discuss strategies for refining your queries to increase your chances of finding informative solutions.
https://ucsb-meds.github.io/teach-me-how-to-google/#1

About the speaker:

Sam Csik (pronounced â€œchickâ€) is the Data Training Coordinator at the National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis (NCEAS) located at UC Santa Barbara, where she is working to develop and teach data science training curricula for the Masterâ€™s of Environmental Data Science (MEDS) program and other data science initiatives across NCEAS and UCSB. She is also co-organizer of R-Ladies Santa Barbara, a local data science group which works to promote diversity in the R community. In her spare time, youâ€™ll typically find her hiking with her pup or cooking family dinners with friends.
